reviewText:
I caught this show for the first time when HBO was running a marathon of every episode. I ended up staying up until 3am to get through them all and within a week had re-watched it all with my friends. This show is brilliant. I can totally understand the other reviews saying this is a love/hate show. Do I love everything these people do? No. But that's what makes me love the show. All of these people have their issues, and it's part of being human. There are more scenes with someone on a toilet in this show than I can count, which just adds to its realness. Sometimes important conversations can happen when you're having a p*ss. :) This show does a great job of NOT following a formula and also showing you that relationships are not cookie-cutter, they can be volatile and unpredictable and still be satisfying.

You won't be able to predict what will happen next on this show. I absolutely love it. Can't wait for Season 2! Several of my girlfriends are getting this for Christmas!!
These guys in line for the bathroom they gave me some pot out of a pipe but it was a stem they kept calling it a stem it was a stem

I'm 20, slightly younger than the "Girls" on this show, but close enough in age that plenty of their problems are relate-able for me. I was really excited for this show - it was like Sex and the City but with younger characters; characters who didn't have great jobs and were NOT yet in a place where they would be really looking for husbands or ready to have children.

Sadly, the first episode left kind of a bad taste in my mouth and so did the following ones until I let the series go about 3/4 the way into the season.

I think my main problem is the central character, Hannah. I really just couldn't bring myself to like her, which is odd because I think the actress who plays her (also the creator of the show!) Lena Dunham is lovely, and I'm taking a leap by assuming she based a lot of Hannah's personality off of herself.

You see, in the first episode she tries to convince her parents to keep financially supporting her by claiming she "feels that she is to voice of her generation...or something (yes, that was heavily paraphrased). I have nothing against aiming big, that's not it. It's just I feel that you can change the world and hold down a paying job at the same time. Also, with the job market still so rocky, wouldn't a better argument be "I just really don't know when I'm going to be able to find a paying job?"

Then later on she blows a huge job interview by making, and I am not kidding, a rape joke. Okay, I must admit that I am absolutely not the master of small talk or impressive job interviews but I feel that you would have to be ABSOLUTELY INCOMPETENT to make a rape joke (!) during a freaking JOB INTERVIEW, even with a friendly, like-minded interviewer. I doubt somebody in middle school would ever make that joke - much less a 25 year old woman. I realize it's just a TV show and it was put in there to make for a "fun" (and really, when are rape jokes ever appropriate?) awkward moment, but seriously?

There are other things that bothered me, for example the (LE GASP!) 22 year old virgin who the others are shocked to discover has not done the deed. Oh, by the way, this is while they are with Hannah who is getting an STD test (guess how it comes out you guyzzz!). Maybe it's just the bitter teen mother in me talking but is it really that odd to find a 22 year old virgin? Not that I believe there is ANYTHING wrong with premarital sex, but why be unflattering shocked when someone hasn't partaken in it yet? Especially when she is only a college student?

I do get that this is just a satire of young womanhood, and this fact has to be taken into thought. Being a girl myself I just don't believe this is how "girls" really are. Maybe it's a New York thing?

EDIT: Haha! Okay judging by the fact that somebody went through my profile and disliked everything I've ever reviewed within a half hour I'm going to assume that somebody REALLY likes this show. I really didn't mean to offend, I'm just being honest about not really liking the show!

A lot of people seem to vehemently hate this show without ever having watched it before. I admit that I was pretty skeptical about "Girls," but after watching just one episode, I found that I absolutely loved it. The entire first season is fantastic. The best thing about the show is the writing, which is incredible. Lena Dunham is incredibly talented. It's hard to believe that she wrote, directed, produced, and starred in this series at such a young age and with very little experience. "Girls" follows the trials and tribulations of four young women who have been out of college for a couple of years and are trying to determine what kind of lives they want to build for themselves in New York City. The show is funny, poignant, honest, and heartwarming, and I can't get enough of it. (It kind of sucks that there are only 10 episodes.) I think the acting is wonderful, and a lot of these characters are much more realistic than the people you typically see portrayed on television. The one character I never really warmed up to at all is Shoshanna, who I think is super annoying (I'm glad she doesn't get nearly as much screen time as the other three girls). Hopefully she will grow on me in Season 2, which I can't wait to see.

Omg! It might have been a good show if I could've gotten over Hannahs awkwardness, it made it painful to watch, she's one of those people that you go out of your way to avoid because they make you feel so uncomfortable it was like looking at a stab wound, not to mention it was hard to see her in a girl role because she looked so much like a guy

I thought the writing was great and I like the characters. However, it is filled with gratuitous sex scenes! Yuck. Can't we have a great sitcom that doesn't get so close to pornography? It seems lazily provocative.

I must be one of the few 20-somethings of this generation that cannot identify with any aspect of the show. I did not find it funny in its strange brand of awkward humor. Even giving it the allowance of television-reality disconnect, nothing seemed to be believable. Maybe it is just a disconnect from the city Girls and me, but this attempt at the next generation of Sex in the City did not land well with me. Although part of the demographic, I am not part of their target audience.
I liked the premise of the show.  However, after watching the first half of the pilot, I realized the vulgarity and pornographic material was not what I wanted to spend my time with.

She can write her away around any illogical setup or self-absorbed unlikable characters who just have a way of looking at life that's a little different from us normal people. They're cooler than us and they're sexually liberated that's for sure and they'll even take it in the out door if you know what I am saying if they really like the guy or girl. There's a lot of great material in here yearning to get out though it's not easy to see the first 6-7 times you watch. I haven't had the time to watch for an eighth time but it has to be in there with the way the media lauds this ground-breaking show that's really shedding new light on something.

There is a lot of eye-rolling and some raw talk about people's bodies and their bathing suit zones. And it does not hurt that Adam Diver is a gigantic hunk of sunshine.

This was so difficult to watch. the characters are whiny and It's just not good. Lena Dunham is a racist and a rape apologist, and it comes out in her work quite obviously. The show doesn't even make sense. There's no way the characters can afford to live in the city like that.  There are no marginalized people in the show, it is all centered on snotty white people. If you like the fact that the male writer (miller) of the show is a rapist, and that Lena and another female writer defended him vehemently, then I guess this is for you. But even before that incident, the show has been problematic and tinged with racism, classism, and anti-LGBTQIAP+ attitudes (having a gay character doesn't cancel that out). Gross all around. And an annoying show to begin with.

hannah is so comfortable with her self!

THIS SHOW IS EFFING BRILLIANT!!!
I had to stop watching this show to write a review, which I have never done for a show or movie...ever. I find myself laughing, yelling, and being emotionally torn all at the same time and I love it. Plus, there are some powerful messages in this show: "I don't like women telling other women, what to do, when to do it, or how to do it." The girls are all so brilliant together and I can feel their raw friendship. Usually, Im really picky on what shows I watch on here, usually only shows with 4 stars and up... but I decided to give this show a try bc I heard Malia Obama was an intern for Lena during the last season (ridiculous, I know, but I love Malia). And to be honest, I am disappointed about the rating of this show on here, I think it is because some people don't quite understand/see the brilliance of the message behind it all! If you want to watch REAL life (hilarious) women put unfair female stigmas to rest all while flaunting their NOT size 0 body, this is the show for you! RAW AND FUNNY AND BRILLANT!
This show is everything! Although I can see myself in all 4 girls, Hannah & I are the same exact person @ times; it's like an outer body experience. Whoa! The writing is phenomenal!

It's self explanatory. It's just that bad. I could write paragraphs about how terrible the story is, but I honestly don't want to. It's a waste of time, and I regret ever watching all 6 seasons. Besides season 5, the story is all meaningless, and the sex scenes are good if you wanna fap to some thick Jewish ass (Not that there's anything wrong with that). Otherwise, it's all a bunch of post college grads, barely, making it in New York City, while getting nude and drugged up in the mean time. The last season doesn't do anything for the characters. There is literally no ending worth watch. All it shows is Hannah her half Middle-eastern (Muslim) baby. That's it. Save your money, or better yet: buy HBO NOW for a month, watch the series, if you really want to, and then watch Game of Thrones to wash everything out. You're welcome
I forced myself to watch it and not being a lackwit enjoyed it. From the stand point of good television and art, it's a great product

I forced myself to watch more than one episode to save others from wasting their time through this review.
Girls is not awkward-cute (from my So-called life to any number of movies where the male or female protagonist is so clueless yet somehow muddles through); it's just disfunctional-pathetic. How did Lena Dunham win awards for this dribble?  Is it because they admired her courage for being naked on her own show?

The two stars are because it is occasionally interesting.  Also, if you're a woman, and your daddy (and/or mommy) never loved you, this show will make you feel better about yourself.

I made it through the whole first episode, started the second, and just couldn't take it anymore. It's both too realistic and unrealistic at the same time. The realism is in the non-existent acting, and the awkward sex scenes, and the unrealistic parts are in how the girls interact. They are just awful with each other. I don't believe that they are friends at all. There is no chemistry or sparkle at all, just whiny, bitchy 20-something women.

Girls is a celebration of narcissism, liberalism, and personal irresponsibility.  As hard as it tries to give a bright face to liberalism, it only succeeds portraying young women in the worst light.  While I think the lead Leah Dunham is pretty funny and talented she should  hide under blankets for setting back the women's movement since this show just highlights neurotic and unhinged behavior.  For a show I didn't like that much, I did watch quite a few episodes from each season.. which I suppose makes me a hypocrite.. or just morbid.
This was on of the funniest shows I have ever seen. Made it through all 6 seasons and it maintained its level of comedy. Comedy is freak'n hard to get right and this show nailed it.
I think it was well written.

Hilarious season ! You must  like a mixture of Sex and the City meets Seinfeld to enjoy this humor. All the character reflect many people we've met in our journey of life. Lena Dunham's character is an odd , reflective, obsessive compulsive ,  often nude and confused with life character. Jessa is a spunky, bisexual whose spontaneous and quite the rule breaking friend. Shoshanna is whiney, sensitive  but sweet over bubbly friend that won't stop talking . Lastly, is Marnie who is the often self obsessed and relationshipholic.  She tends to draw the attention on herself whenever possible .The first season explains each character and the difficulties of being in your early 20 somethings. Many laughs and many cringes~ I highly recommend this to anyone who also likes odd humor .
Lovee this show. Very realistic relationships between women!

Hannah disrespects everyone around her, especially herself, then begs for handouts from those very people. I wanted to watch further for any hint at plot development, aka growth at becoming a real human, but I couldn't get past the 6th episode.

I feel like I've watched all the GREAT shows under the sun, so after I heard about this I was willing to try. I personally laughed out loud a few times and also said wtf to a lot of moments. I think the people who rate this as 1 star are taking it way too seriously, or don't have that much of a sense of humor. It's goofy, it's not 100% based on her actual life, yes..parts, but also not completely fictional. but C'mon there ARE actual people who do have these types of personalities in the world, especially college students. I think it's relatable on some sort of level, but altogether it's just a comical, awkward, some-what slow moving tv show.

This show is just awful. The writing is bad, the acting is bad. Everything about this show is totally asinine. Lena Dunham is just gross, everything about her is just repulsive. The characters are shallow and unlikable, and not in a compelling way. You can't help but not care about any of them. The jokes are tasteless too, mostly vulgar and shocking, which can be done well when context and timing is right. But Dunham just says off putting things for the sake of shock value, none of it is funny really, it just makes you uncomfortable....Again, not in a good way. I watched a few episodes and I just can't get into this garbage. Game of Thrones has a lot of sex and nudity but it is done well, this is just pure trash. I don't know why the ratings are so high and why this crap hasn't been canceled. If this is all it takes to have a show air on HBO then maybe I should write and direct, I'm full of terrible ideas that I'm sure mainstream media would appreciate and pay me for, not that any of it is warranted. At least if I did I would have enough common decency to at least make it mediocre at best. Dunham writes and directs crap without even trying and gets paid for it, and that appears to be her only talent.

I am open-minded, and a fan of HBO's talent pool and style of shows. The Wire, True Detective S1, Sopranos, and Game of Thrones, and Curb are among my favorite shows of all time. Also, I'm not in this show's demographics as a straight man living in the suburbs of the Deep South.

I did not like this show, yet I can see its appeal. I watched 3 episodes entirely and skimmed the rest of Season One through Season Five. The camera work, dialogue, NYC setting, and theme of finding yourself in your mid to late 20s after the Great Recession were the positives. What I couldn't stand is how vapid, superficial, and (intentionally?) mistake-prone these characters were. I didn't care for them or their hedonism or their privileged outlook. By the end of Season Five, it seemed the writers made a diagram of all the characters and made them sleep with one another. I have a need to finish stories so I was forced to skim the rest of the show, but in the end nothing really changed.

New York City is one of my favorite travel destinations. I visit it 2-3 times a year, and often overheard people similar to the characters while eating dinner or drinking coffee. Think mostly white, upper middle-class people who attended liberal arts colleges or art schools. This show gave a glimpse of those social circles, but the novelty wore off 3 episodes in.

There is no excuse anymore to watch a show because there's nothing else on. You don't even have to leave HBO either. Another show of theirs which I'm binging is Westworld, and it is FAR more worth my time than Girls.

This series is probably more geared to young women in their early to mid twenties but I found it to be interesting and entertaining anyway. I have two beautiful, very secure daughters in this age range and I married young and became a mom a year later so I'm a little surprised at the immaturity and insecurity at times but feel like it's probably a better depiction of the way things are for many women this age as opposed to my experience and how my daughter's think and live their lives.
The friendships and different personalities mixing make for what I consider an entertaining series. I can't say it's my favorite due to my age probably but it's in its tenth season so they're doing a lot right! I find definite similarities between Girls and Sex & The City which I loved!
Finally, I believe that most women (and young men actually) of any age could relate to this as even if you're not in your twenties, at some point you've probably been there or felt that.

Mixed bag- and I'm not sure that I'm their target demographic-  stuff that's not great:  scripts seem contrived sometimes.  Virtually every female character is rudderless, is racked by extreme self-doubt or over-compensation, and chose their parents wisely enough to receive > $10K/year walkin-around $.  I realize that it's not a Census survey, but when you combine Money from Mommy w/ the young woman flailing emotionally, well, they take a bunch of poetic license.  Every 20-something main character is also very self-centered.  They show little awareness of others; even their emotional intimates.  For me, this limited my interest level to a couple of shows in any "mini binge."

Good stuff:  Lena is a gifted actress.  Wicked sense of humor and ability to laugh at how she beats herself up worse than anyone else can.  Reminds me of Woody Allen's early stuff. Her character is relaxed w/ her uneven vocational skill set, sexual appetite, body image stuff, etc.  The other characters either don't get as much help from the script, or I'm too dense to see the nuanced artistry.  I'm not much for characters' names, but the woman who is the Brooke Shields look-alike has some great material, but drops into Stepford Wife.  Maybe that's her role.  Dunno.  The obligatory gay guy, (closely linked to Lena's character, but I don't want to ruin it...), acts like a cardboard cut-out.  No complexity or layers.  Just shows some stereotype affectations.

Lena's parents, esp her mother, are excellent.  Mom REALLY nails it, but doesn't get much face time,at least thru episode 9.

I wanted to like this series. The camera work is nice. But when Hanna blew her job interview in episode 2, by "joking" about the interviewer being responsible for a bunch of date-rapes, I had to pause and actually say out loud "WTF???!!!" I can't waste any more precious brain cells or minutes with a character so absolutely unsympathetic. I know plenty of people with actual tough breaks, and to watch a bunch of spoiled brats whine about their lack of direction ("because Mom and Dad spoiled me!") is disgusting, not funny. Yes, everyone's problems are important and real to them, but these are not problems that are interesting to me....the characters seem mostly tortured by the lack of engagement that comes with mommy and daddy providing everything and expecting nothing more than your utter happiness.

having heard about Lena Dunham for some time, this was the first time i'd ever actually seen her in action, and all i can say is Lena is utterly fearless - and perhaps add that her 3 female cohorts are very easy on the eyes and great actresses... Zosia Mamet is mesmerizing - almost like watching Tom Hanks do Forrest Gump... the show is hilarious at times, painful at times, sad at times, gripping at times, but always believable - it is simply a slice of reality... and the sparks really begin to fly near the end of the first season - i'm sold on Lena... and regarding the many comments about Lena's courageousness for her nude scenes and Gaby Hoffman's feeling that the notion of nudity as bravery is something of an insult: When I hear people say that about Lena I cringe, because I find it predicated on the notion that she somehow wouldnt feel comfortable with her body. That the bravery is coming from a place that shes doing it in spite of something. in spite of Gaby Hoffman's take that it is an insult to believe Lena was courageous for doing the nude scenes - it does take courage to swim against the current of this deranged culture and its incessant conditioning about body-image... Lena's courage is opening new doors...

The bad: The show reeks of privileged white Northeasterner girls.  It covers every type within that demographic, but it doesn't drift anywhere past that.  As a male Asian-Canadian (expat), it's not just really hard to relate, and at worst it's a bit tone deaf (i.e. white privilege).  I can't watch this show with my white friends, which was the mistake I made the first time. We enjoy the show differently.  1-star on this measure.

The good: Being in my early 30's, it's awesome to see a show about all the awkwardness of growing up during your 20's in today's world.  5-stars by this measure.  I love that a lot of new shows are addressing our generation.

This show is definitely a must see!! I was binge watching "Shameless" & I was so sad when the series ended & I didn't think I could find another show that I would be just as excited about to watch. A few days later, I stumbled upon "Girls" which has an amazingly talented cast & the writing is absolutely superb. Lena really shows her character's true authentic self & isn't afraid to show any emotions or hold back in her acting. You can definitely relate to any character's storyline. Even 8 years after a really bad breakup, I was bawling at the breakup of Hannah & Adam (***SPOILER ALERT)*** after watching season 4. I vastly related to both emotions between man & woman which I never understood before until now. Also, NYC plays such an important role in this storyline & having lived there for 6 years, I can say this series no boubt takes me back to a great chapter & learning experience in my life.

I watched the first two episodes. The production value and character development and all that are great... it's just that, if this is the voice of my generation, WE ARE DOOMED.

OK I'm sure we'll be fine actually, but still. There's a profound lack of wisdom, integrity or character here. And I'm sure (if I watch further) that these girls are great about progressive values like tolerance and inclusion, but I'm reminded of a great passage from the Screwtape Letters (a work of fiction in which an experienced demon gives lessons to a newbie):

"The use of Fashions in thought is to distract the attention of men from their real dangers. We direct the fashionable outcry of each generation against those vices of which it is least in danger and fix its approval on the virtue nearest to that vice which we are trying to make endemic. The game is to have them running about with fire extinguishers whenever there is a flood, and all crowding to that side of the boat which is already nearly gunwale under. Thus we make it fashionable to expose the dangers of enthusiasm at the very moment when they are all really becoming worldly and lukewarm; a century later, when we are really making them all Byronic and drunk with emotion, the fashionable outcry is directed against the dangers of the mere "understanding".

"Cruel ages are put on their guard against Sentimentality, feckless and idle ones against Respectability, lecherous ones against Puritansm; and whenever all men are really hastening to be slaves or tyrants we make Liberalism the prime bogey."

The problems these girls are most against (e.g. being judgmental) are probably the extremes of the directions they most need to move (e.g. more discernment). ...a lesson for us all I guess.

I went into this hoping it would be a show about feminist women in their 20s. It's not. These are women and they could even be described as somewhat intelligent women (in an academic sense)...but these are NOT women who think and behave like feminists. Strong, emotionally intelligent women don't allow themselves to be denigrated, used, and abused. There is no liberation or strength in begging for attention or clinging to scraps of affection. The only character I remotely liked is Marnie's boyfriend. His friend (I don't even remember his name) is one of the most annoying, appalling characters I have ever come across. Just repulsive.

There are funny moments, but they don't compensate for the rest of it. I hope young women don't watch this and think it's healthy behavior. This could have been such an amazing platform to display strong female characters. Wasted opportunity.

I was pleasantly surprised to find this "new" HBO TV series - normally I'm not interested in young 20's generation stuff as they're usually boringly predictable. However, was I in for a fantastic surprise - the lines are exactly what my girlfriends and I would say to each other years ago (when we were in our 20's) --- I could relate with few characters' personalities, the constant changing of minds which had me roaring with laughter remembering how we used to SWEAR we'd "mean it" and end up doing the very opposite. I loved all the characters which is so rare as I tend to be very finicky with characters' personalities - but all the actors did an AMAZING job of portraying honest real life like tendencies young adults are learning, discovering, exploring, experimenting.  What also delighted me was of some of the surprising slap-stick (Slapstick is a style of humor involving exaggerated physical activity which exceeds the boundaries of normal physical comedy) which artfully and skillfully punctuated endings magnificently.  This is from an ADD-seen-everything-get-bored-easily-as-I-can-predict avid film lover... and I was so pleased with GIRLS performance. I hope there is more season coming up!

A trip into a world you could know only if you were a young woman in her 20s just out of college. The angst. The  the obsession with self and boys. Sex at every turn or lacking sex the emotional drama of virginity in a post 20 year-old. This series holds nothing back and is better for it. The dialogue is familiar to anyone who hangs out with this generation, but the emotions are compact into each 30 minute segment. The cast is uniformly impressive and more than believable, they appear to be their roles. This is not easy viewing and listening. For my generation 50 years down the road it is a welcome training film that accesses a culture that is far removed from what I had and thereby all the more interesting.

This is the most ridiculous show ever. It's like watching a train wreck, you don't want to watch it but you can't help it. The main character is played by Lena Dunham who said she created this show because she couldn't find any shows that she could relate to. Who wants to relate to a narcissistic, self-absorbed loser. She made this character to be someone nobody in my reality can relate to. The other characters are interesting and can be dynamic...but not enough energy is focused on the whole cast. The first season starts out interesting, then you spend the rest of your time trying to figure out why you are watching this show. Lena Dunham is writer, director, and main character. The other characters have a fashion sense, but Lena wears these awful clothes that nobody should have let her on screen with.

If you have a choice don't watch this train wreck. You will never get that time back.

How does anyone like this? The characters are shallow, horrible people with simply no sense of... anything, really. They don't understand themselves, they don't understand their friends, they don't understand much about the world they live in - and they don't seem to care. Furthermore, nothing really seems to happen in the show. No, that's not true... plenty enough happens capable of spinning a good story, but the characters themselves are so lacking (I hate to even call them "characters") that nothing really comes of anything. Thank god my life isn't full of corpses like this.

Speaking of spin, hats off to the writers for creating something so terribly bad, you'll remember the distaste.

You either love or hate Hannah. Or like me have this ridiculous love hate relationship with her character. Overall an accurate portrayal of just how ridiculous and confusing life can be in your twenties. The ups and downs of relationships all the while trying to survive in the concrete jungle. This is a show that explores many different aspects of life, specifically sexual experiences and the baggage of it all as an slightly "overweight" woman. As Hannah breaks out her shell as upcoming raw writer, not only does she find herself but she accepts herself and her relationships no matter how difficult they may be. I love how straight forward a lot of cast members are and it is an overall enjoyable show (if "gossip" drama is your kind of thing).

I recently began watching Girls, S4, on HBO. Coming in so late to the "party" I was a bit annoyed with Hannah, but after binge watching seasons 1 & 2 on Amazon Prime I have come to understand Hannah and her friends a little better. It's akin to the same story Candace Bushnell told 20 years ago with Sex and the City; writer living in New York trying to find herself in life and love, but Girls offers something SATC never did, depth. I was surprised by how much I enjoyed spending time with this group. Hannah, Marnie, Shoshanna, and Jessa are four of the most self-centered characters I have ever seen on television (aside from the aforementioned SATC), and yet I get them.

Great show! Sad that only the first two seasons are offered with my Amazon Prime subscription and that I'll have to pay extra in order to see the rest of the shows.  It's easy to fall in love with the various characters.

I can see that for a lot of people Girls just wouldn't be their thing.  Like some people hate chocolate.  But if watching a handful of deeply flawed young adults trying to navigate careers and relationships and life in general sounds interesting to you, then you might just like Girls.

For people who do like this particular flavor of TV, the quality of Girls is top notch.  The acting is completely engrossing, maybe more so that anything else on TV right now.  This is enhanced by the brilliant script, which is at the same time innovative and completely natural.  Visually it's as cool and urban as you would expect for a show set in Manhattan.  I love Girls, my super-picky non TV-watching husband loves it.  It's art, and it's wonderful.

Not really liking this show?  Just watch up to the end of episode 4 - Hannah's Diary - one of the greatest moments ever formulated in a TV drama.  You need ever moment of the first 4 episodes to fully appreciate it, and it is so worth it.

I kept seeing the posters for this show in the subway so I thought I'd check it out since it's on Amazon Prime.  Obviously, I'm not the correct target demographic and it shows.  I finished the 10 episodes of Season 1 but in all honesty, I "hate" watched it.  Characters are selfish and want their every whim and desire just handed to them (the very first scene at the restaurant tells you basically all you need to know about character motivation) but for me, that's not entertainment.  I live in Manhattan and run into these characters far too often. A few months ago I was going to be out of town for a few weeks in an area with no internet. So, I downloaded Girls onto my iPad because I saw that the first two seasons were available for free through Amazon prime. I had no prior impression of this show besides a few gifs I saw floating around the Internet.

At first I found this show overwhelmingly annoying. I felt like I could not relate to any of the main characters' personalities at all. HOWEVER, with no internet to provide me with other shows, I eventually continued watching. AND I WEIRDLY CAME TO LOVE THIS SHOW AND ACTUALLY CARE ABOUT THE CHARACTERS.

Although the characters are hard to take at times, they are entertaining and (most of) the situations they go through are 100% relatable. After season two the show really comes into its own and ends up being addictive. Also, the main guy characters in the show are amazing (although I saw the new Star Wars before seeing this show and so that was weird at first).

Overall, this show is great and I have binge-watched all the episodes up to the most recent episode in season five. I have no regrets. Give this show a shot, it may seem just ok at first but it gets much, much better. This show is a wonderful mix a comedy and drama.

I kept hearing how great this show was from several friends so I decided to try it.  Maybe it's my age of 46 that prevented me from embracing it but I swear that from the opening scene I just absolutely despised the main character.  Her entitlement and self-centeredness was so off-putting!!  Maybe it's just easier for me to relate to her parents' characters but I found myself hating them too for raising such a loser.  Scene two, she is sleeping with her friend or roommate and they are physically entwined (but not sexually).  As a teenager I either spent the night with friends or had friends sleepover at my house almost every weekend and that kind of stuff just does not happen in real life, and quite thankfully.  Seeing Lena Dunham having sex with her boyfriend was nauseating because she is so unlikeable in every way.  I feel like the cast of characters are just a bunch of whiny millennials who are totally clueless but want to come off like they are so wise and witty.  I made it through about three episodes before calling it quits.  Again, I think it's an age thing here, but if these people represent real milennials then God help us all.

Girls is a fun, interesting show that portraits characters attempting to grow into adulthood and all the challenges that go along with that.  Are they selfish and narcissistic as well as intitled?  Yes!  They are kids in their 20's who don't know anything else.  They are LEARNING to 'adult.' That is the whole point of the show...  Just enjoy it and don't take it too seriously!  It's intertainment!

I came to this series late and wondered what the fuss was about.  What I found was a sweet, laugh out loud at times series of young souls trying to find where they fit in a country that has kept them young and then suddenly expects them to grow up.  Lena Dunham has created an amazing look at her generations struggles to grow up and find their voice.  Its a universal, really ageless experience since the post Vietnam generations have come of age.  Nicely cast, Dunham and Adam Driver have a great chemistry and awkwardness and the balance of the cast is excellent as well.  Well worth a binge night!

I don't understand how there could be SO many people that like the show and the fact that she gets awards for it is preposterous!!!!!!! Maybe alot of the good reviews are fake or too many people watch it while being stoned or some other reason but this show is just garbage, plain and simple. The situation with her roommate and her boyfriend is based in reality and I've known people like that but Lena being the writer and then portraying the lead actress and that guy she is with is just horrid and I just want to go back and unsee everything that had to do with Lena. The only worthwhile part was the stuff with her roommate and her boyfriend storyline, but that made up VERY little of what I watched. CANNOT believe this garbage was renewed for 6 seasons, but there is smtg VERY wrong with viewers these days! As a fairly privileged Ivy-League-educated millennial living in New York, I totally get where this show is going. And sometimes it's AMAZING and totally encapsulates what I perceive to be our collective experience as a demographic. But sometimes it's just too cringey in its characterizations, which sure, are part of what it's going for, but which also don't feel real even in a "truth is stranger than fiction" way.

Maybe this will come in later seasons, but the show doesn't have a working, driven, successful character. It doesn't even have to be a main character, just someone who maybe has a real job, is in their early 20s, who has challenges (even if they're not explored by the show) that resemble those faced by someone who is actually directly in a position to "be successful" or (god forbid) earn a living. There are no contemporary foils to the characters the show follows that get an iota of screen time.

That said, liked the show. Will probably watch season 2.

I'm giving it a four instead of a five only because I can't recommend it to everyone I know. [Not everybody can handle so much frank sexual content.]  But I LOVED it! I found these four neurotic, quirky, and utterly self-involved creatures to be intelligent and charming no matter much I asked myself if I was like that at their age. [I'm thirty-mumble years older than they are.] Of course, I'd be remiss if I didn't also mention how interesting it is to also study the men in their lives; most shows about a group of women don't go there and I found it added incredible depth to the story lines. All that intellectual stuff aside, Lena Dunham makes me want to shed my clothes and run down the street, extra padding and all, shouting, "I am beautiful, smart, and funny. So there!" :)

70 year old grandmother of 5 granddaughters.  I tried to see the show for its value add.  I just could not get into it.  I think of myself as a pretty liberal, open minded woman. I see the value add in the struggle young people face with life challenges and how sex has its role in helping you find your place in this world.  I tried to accept seeing it on screen and really wanted to be able to accept the value add but it was hard.  I guess I still have the illusion that a young, maturing young woman can have a value system that gives a woman the option to choose value add relationships.  I just saw too much loss in meaningless relationships that can be costly to a young woman's ego and self esteem.  I thought the character development was great.  I love the concept and wish there was more depth in the decisions these young women are making.  I hope that I am not sounding like a critical grandmother.  I fully acknowledge where I am coming from and have the greatest respect for the writing, directing and development of these characters.  Truly I am not of this generation and I respect the wisdom of this generation.

As a 60s feminist, I am appalled by the depths to which these pathetic young women subjugate and demean themselves for the men in their lives.  I never dreamed that I would see such giant steps backward in feminism.  In fact, I would prefer to be a woman in the 1940s where men at least respected women......and that is saying a lot...I would hate for my granddaughter to see this show and be influenced in any way by these lazy, neurotic, helpless, pathetic, dysfunctional creatures.

It's an amazing, weird, intentionally awkward, deeply felt performance that is riveting even in moments when the character is appalling. I shudder to think that this show has run as long as it has, based on what I saw, or that anyone could possibly relate to any one of the characters in it.  Just my 3cents (1cent added due to inflation).

Vapid.  I hate the show almost as much as I hate all of the characters.  None of the show is believable; there is no explanation for how the characters afford their apartments, wardrobes and relatively lavish lifestyles in NYC while paying off student debt and constantly being in between jobs.  The glorification of alcoholism is also off-putting.  This show seeks to cash in on stereotypes about millennial age women, all the while making them out to be the absolute worst representations of this generation of women.  Anything but feminist.  The show shamelessly also exploits every stereotype about gay men there is out there.

This show centers around a spoiled 24 yr old girl who acts every bit the spoiled child. She can't hold a job, she lets her friends pay her bills, she strives for the attention of a guy who wants to pretend like she's an 11 yr old girl while they're having sex (barf), and she's obviously oblivious as to how the real world operates. It's extremely annoying to even watch her. The group of "friends" all sleep with the same men. Unfortunately, I watched 5-6 episodes before finally giving up and accepting that it was a complete waste of time.

I am almost certain that you are supposed to laugh at something that is billed as comedy. I just couldn't do it. This was like going to a nice posh restaurant only to be served leftovers that smell of cheese and old feet. The only time I laughed was when I was pulling out a cuticle and accidentally tore a bit of flesh. When you aren't even religious and find yourself praying for it to end, yeah, that's when you know it's a true blue stinker.

i'm on the fence here. It's a completely love hate relationship with this show. I hate the characters and all that they stand for, yet I'm completely drawn to them in a very twisted sort of way. But maybe that's the catch.  Lena Dunham has managed to create a show that is controversial, clearly successful, and yet the characters are "hated" by some (if not many). But I guess that hate at least evokes some emotion that keeps viewers interested. I'd like to say that I can just stop watching one episode, but I continue to watch it in hopes that one, if not all of the characters will get out of their own ass, take financial security of their lives, stop being so selfish and entitled, and become a grown up.  But alas, I'm disappointed every episode. I can only find little joys in moments when someone refreshes their memory of the things that prevent them from becoming fully functioning responsible, independent women.  There are tender moments in the episode that remind you that these women are human, but again (I guess as in reality), they fall back to their entitled ways.

The quirky girls on GIRLS remind me of my college friends.  And what the show does so well is to show them in several dimensions, something most shows lack.  Yes Jessa is harebrained and mercurial, but she is also deeply loyal. Yes Shoshana is superficial, at first, and too concerned about looks and fashion, but we also find out she has a puritan moral code.

If you don't like GIRLS, then it is probably because you are a GUY!  But guys would understand girls better if they'd watch the show.  The show depicts young women in all their growing pains toward becoming mature, self-actualized women. What I like best is that the girls are shown warts and all. None are perfectly beautiful or glorious model-like creatures. Each is shown with all her flaws, both physical and emotional, and I've come to love each of them, well except Shoshana, but I'm working on loving her too.

Good grief. What an irresponsible child Lena Dunham's character is. I suppose it's never truly the fault of the child but of the parents who taught their daughter it was reasonable top expect to be supported well into adulthood.

First episode begins with her parents cutting her off and telling her to get a job. I think the mom was supposed to be the antagonist, at least from the main character's perspective, but I was cheering her on. I thought, "so this is going to be a show about her really embracing independence and adulthood and getting her life together, great!" Alas, I was too optimistic. It was in fact a half hour of whining about how unfair her parents were to expect her to support herself, and her friends encouraging her to try to persuade her parents to change their minds.

Great tv shows have characters that are challenged and grow, that have depth of character that informs their struggles with life issues..... by contrast, Girls is a show about immature children who don't want to face reality, much less grow up, because working to pay bills and being a responsible person just is no fun. Now that I think of it, that's probably why it's popular with my fellow "millenials".

To those who disagree with me, feel free because I don't care. This was effing terrible! The characters were just like everybody else described them--rude, selfish, arrogant, conceited, unrealistic sluts! I couldn't get past three episodes and those three episodes were literally about one girl getting pregnant, thinking about murdering her child with an abortion and then abandoning that idea while leaving her friends in the clinic to wonder why she never showed, another girl who has absolutely no self respect or class and sleeps around with some POS because her parents told her to put her college education to work and start paying her own bills and then gets high, acts like an idiot, and finds out she has an STD, a different girl who is bossy, unappreciative of her boyfriend treating her like the queen she is and wants him to treat her like she's worth less than dirt, and one last girl who talks too much, has like no friends, and makes a big deal out of the fact that she's embarrassed (not proud) of the fact that she waited for someone who was worth her time, love, attention, and affection.

They prance around and slut around and act like idiots and expect the viewers to somehow identify with them or have sympathy for them, and I just can't do it. The pathetic attempts at humor are dry and stupid and this is just not worth my time. Or money, but you know, thank God it was free.

First off, since I turn 65 in three months, I fall laughably outside the "Girls" viewer target market.  Yet thanks to sharp writing about certain universal truths of young adulthood, I could easily relate to these young women's emotional ups and downs.  I had roommates too in my twenties and not only was I definitely a Marnie, so were they.  No can't-get-it-together Hannahs...just some soon-regretted risk-seeking Jessa moments and Shoshanna freakouts.  So every Girls episode left me marveling that Hannah could attract (much less keep) anyone's positive attention and friendship.  I kept watching all of Season 1 in hopes that I would witness her messed-up pudgy little caterpillar self evolve into a beautiful mature butterfly.  Maybe that happens in Season 2.  I'll watch and find out.

I loved it. Not because its entirely believable, as its not. Not because all the women are gorgeous, as they're not.
Nor because the drama concerns things of earthshaking importance, as it doesnt. I gave this series four stars because
I found I just loved watching a fairly ordinary-looking young woman make her way in her young adult world,
with her motly group of girl and guy-friends, focused on the real and often immature things that many, even fairly
bright "transition-age youths 18-25 are doing and thinking about these days with in the real world. In bringing this to the screen,
as writer and producer, Lena Dunham has made a marvelous contribution giving us a fairly realistic window into young womanhood.
I don't see any other TV show doing that. Congrats Lena, and to do that at your age!

An incredibly shallow, superficial look on the lives of college aged women in New York city. The writing attempts to be diverse and "hip" but falls quite flat when trying illustrate these young girls lives. The show makes it clear that it is primarily focused on the theme of sex, you will constantly be bombarded with sexual pretense and awkward scenes that are attempting to make sex less of a polarizing subject in the context of women but ends up making itself look unnecessary and gross. This show has a bit of an agenda and that is something that needs to be stressed, having an agenda when writing fiction is to this day one of the most polar topics of debate with writers. As for the agenda itself: expect an EXTREMELY left winged take on daily life and conflict, uncomfortably so in my opinion. Overall the show takes managed to keep me interested for about 3-4 episodes and then I sort of lost interest. Some might enjoy this show, some may not.

I didn't even finish watching the first season - there wasn't enough depth as to the "whys" of the female characters and the males all seemed completely one-dimensional.  I just couldn't find one character I could sympathize with.  Maybe if I continued watching I would have gotten more insight, but it was too depressing for me to continue. Sorry, I just couldn't hang in there...but I'm giving it the second star for originality.

I loved every minute of Girls. Lena Dunham is an amazing writer and reinvented the "real women" sitcom that television truly needed. The show is melodramatic, yet honest. It's funny, but can be very emotional. But most importantly, it's smart and realistic. Although not all of us live in NYC and live the luxurious lives of women, they struggle with the same problems that real women do. The women face insecurities, relationship problems, jealousy, money issues, etc. just as all women do. Most importantly, the show focuses on the point that these women seem to have it all, yet still find problems with every situation...as a woman, I can 100% vouch for this. It doesn't portray the girls as pretentious (because they really aren't), they are just naive. I'm so glad Girls is such a hit, because it filled a void that needed a new kind of (dark??) comedy. This is it.

Been meaning to watch Girls and I'm so glad I did. Lena Dunham has shared the full range of her emotions in a wonderfully ironic voice. Girls falls into the dramedy genre of comedy so the personalities and situations are exaggerated just enough. The cast is great, the guys too, and her Hannah gets away with being painfully neurotic because she's truly endearing. The low-rent environment depicts Brooklyn as expected when you're fresh out of school and willing to survive in New York for a yet unknown purpose. New York attracts all kinds of interesting and weird people that get into all kinds of situations. I love how the characters evolve with each experience, ridiculous at times, funny, intelligent, uncertain, and laughably gross, too, brutally honest.
I wish I didn't have to buy more seasons to finish watching.  I might just stick with Netflix.

This is actually pretty funny and very quick humor so you have to listen so you don't miss anything.  It reminds me (sort of) of a Sex In The City with four good friends, but these friends aren't well established and don't care about hair, makeup, clothes, or shoes.  They fight among themselves and lose job regularly.  It's actually total opposite of the girls on Sex In The City but similar in that it's about four girls and their experiences with men.  I enjoyed the first season and am looking forward to watching the other three seasons.  The thing that annoys me a lot is that Prime ONLY lets us view Season 1, and then we "have" to pay to watch the other seasons.  Not right!!  Netflix is better with giving you ALL the seasons, but I don't think this is on Netflix yet.

By the time I got through the third episode, I was over it! It's boring and lackluster. The characters are self serving and two dimensional. No depth or meat to them. While I applaud any show that promotes women's sexuality in a positive way, by the third episode all I could think was that this show is just mild porn with no real plot. The Hannah character is especially pathetic, constantly crawling back to a boy who cannot give her what she needs, emotionally or sexually. How is that a positive role model? In fact they all act sexually immature, like twelve year old girls who are looking at an anatomy book. I had to stop watching or my eyes would have been stuck permanently rolling. If you enjoy this, then kudos to you, but for me there are better female role models on Game of Thrones!!

I've read the negative reviews, but luckily I took them with a grain of salt. This show would appeal to a somewhat narrow demographic, and a male in his mid-40's is nowhere near the target audience here. It's unsurprising that people outside of this range would be immediately turned off. It doesn't speak to you, but that doesn't mean it isn't done well. To millennials, "GIRLS" speaks the subtleties and distinctions that have permeated our language and the increasingly complex ways that we communicate. No generation before us can relate to having lived through this explosion of media and communication technology, the removal of personal interaction in favor of hundreds of ever-growing and changing media, and the confusion that stems from our immense and ever-increasing scope of technological presence, and how this new reality contends with our efforts to ground ourselves into a stable adulthood. That said, this is not at all a realistic show in the sense of the characters' mindsets. It's raw in every facet and over-the-top brutally honest, but it doesn't represent a typical mid-20's female (at least no one I've ever known), but the beauty of it is how imaginable and realistically it's portrayed, despite the ridiculousness of their circumstances and terrible choices. Truthfully, this show makes me grateful I have never sunk so low in my life. But as much as it makes me cringe, the humanity and depth, the increasingly poor decisions, the open ridicule they give and receive, I find it all so compelling. I wouldn't watch a show that mimics my existence. In this case, I enjoy the hyperbolic, excessive, self-indulgent, impulsive, total clustermess of the character's lives and decisions. I've never seen or read anything quite like this.
I've read negative reviews that a lot of young women my age can't "relate" to the characters. But a show about completely typical, well-rounded individuals wouldn't make it to HBO. If you DO feel like these people are completely just like you, well... I'm sorry... I hope you're doing okay.
As I said, it's not for everyone. I indulged in watching it alone, figuring my fiance wouldn't appreciate it, so I wouldn't subject him to it. But yesterday I craved it, apologized in advance in case he hated it, and then he sat through a few episodes, ending up mildly impressed, laughing a few times, and asking questions about the characters' backgrounds. "GIRLS" definitely isn't going to attract most typical straight males in general (probably, no judgment at all), but as a media director, editor, and movie buff, my fiance commented that it was objectively well done and he appreciated the humor and artistic style. But he's probably not going to request it again, and that's fine. It really isn't for everybody.

I can't honestly say I like it; two episodes (in case the first was an aberration) and I'm done. No point, not much plot, just sort of a Seinfeld-like bunch of 20-somethings plodding through their pointless lives, but without the Seinfeld comedy, insight, or much anything else. Perhaps it should die after one season. If, in the unlikely event someone actually liked it, they could just watch season 1 for a second time, there's nothing much memorable so it would be newly-dull all over again.

It seems to be aimed at taking the place of Sex and the City for the next generation, however in Girls, I do not see an actual reason for the show, there are no lessons learned, the characters are slightly less likeable than those of SATC, and it just seems more average in every respect. From what I gather, that's the point of the show, it's just an account of modern-day life for 20 somethings, and that's not really of interest to me, personally.

This series clearly is of the love / hate variety, as the reviews indicate. As a 64 y/o male, I'm light years away from the intended  audience demographic, as I was also for Sex in the City, to which it must inevitably be compared (4 women dating and surviving in NYC). I refer to it as "Sex in the City- the Next Generation." Female characters younger and less affluent than the precursor, but to my mind equally as interesting, if contrived. I do not understand the vitriol common to so many of the negative reviews. I find the show well written and entertaining as depictions of a generation I know nothing about, other than from the point of view of a parent - i.e. an outsider. If the characters are self absorbed and vapid, they reflect reality. Who at that age isn't a tad narcissistic?  I don't believe that I found the characters of Sex and the City likable either, but that didn't keep me from watching and enjoying  those shows. Lena Dunham appears to have less collaborators writing this show than the group which authored Sex and the City, and for that she should be commended.

I will have no hesitation, and look forward to, renting and watching the remaining seasons.

I am a 61 year old woman and I Love Girls! Marathon watched 1st season when I retired. Have 2 more seasons to go and am looking forward to each episode. Love the neurotic east coast characters, the sex, the settings, the after show analysis, all of it! I do not watch with my Midwest born and raised husband. Girls is, well, a girl thing.

Most unusual program about the sort of people who lead humdrum lives
and are seldom noticed in entertainment.
No glamour, no stereotypes, the protagonist is a sort of "anti star".  A woman in difficult
circumstances, living like a student after college even though she is privileged.
She strips off in a matter of fact way and has sex that may or may not be
enjoyable.  She says she hates herself, which must be ruinous.  She doesn't show
a 'film star body', it is a body, treated as a generic woman's. She has ambition and grit.
She is plain spoken and intelligent and fearless, all in a quiet matter of fact way.
This isn't entertainment that distracts us with a wonderful fantasy.  It is like a look
down the street which turns out to be more interesting than expected.

Smart and witty and oh-so-truthful. This show depicts 20-somethings' characteristics so well, you'll relate to each of the protagonists in your own way and be rooting for them to succeed (to dump that terrible boyfriend, to quit that underpaying job, or to yell at deliverers of bad advice). It's brilliant. Lena Dunham brings up things NO ONE talks about, that no one ever WANTS to talk about. You suddenly feel vindicated for the struggle you put up against the ugly things we faced growing up. You're suddenly not haunted by embarrassing high school memories because someone else is saying it happened to them, too. I laughed out loud often and finished the whole season in three nights.

This series is delightful in its modern approach to young people making their way in our screwed-up world. The treatment from the perspective of young women is refreshing if somewhat governed by previous movies and TV shows. Really, except for the frank treatment of sex and bodily functions, is that different from That Girl and other precursors. But I am having no trouble watching it and enjoying the nicely delineated characters, which avoid most cliches. These are believable characters, who are fun to watch.

Love it. My parents wouldn't, but I sure do. It's witty, tantalizing, uncomfortable, and full of relatable experiences shared by girls in our contemporary society. A great watch, and I'm on my third time of the second season. It hasn't gotten old yet!

Sometimes awkward for awkward's sake, GIRLS is an unflinching look at the lives of millennials trying to make it in The Big Apple. As such, it's both the anti-SEX & THE CITY and entirely beholden to SEX & THE CITY, and it reveals some moments of truth that have seldom if ever been examined on screen. GIRLS is raw and unflinching in its depiction of navigating friendship, careers, identity, and most of all sex. I watched the first season years after it made its HBO debut. At times I was annoyed by protagonist Hannah Horvath and her completely self-absorbed, self-delusional, shlumpadinka behavior, particularly in regard to her parents and the roommate who let her crash rent-free. But at other times, I totally identified with her -- and I'm old enough to be her mother. The season ender, in which her boyfriend accuses her of being a "monster" for seeming to reject his sudden commitment to their relationship just wrecked me. I thought, if she had nagged at him to make their relationship more permanent or insisted that he move in, he probably would have thought she was clingy and would been the first to break and run. But Hannah's low self-esteem has been a running theme of the show, so his accusations rang true.  Kudos to series creator, director, and star Lena Dunham. I finally get what all the hoopla was about.

It's a good show... but not for me. Watching this show was like a poorly made college decisions: I tried it, I didn't really enjoy it, but I thought maybe I'll get over that and it'll be better as I keep going, yet in the end I realized I shouldn't watch the rest of the seasons.

Again, this show might hit the mark for a lot of people, but it just wasn't in the cards for me. I was interested as far as ending the first season, but not enough to get me to watch four more.

I avoided watching this show until I kept hearing about it enough that I thought I'd give it a try. The only reason I kept the painful, illogical and hedonistic misadventures of Lena Dunham's questionably fiction character "Hannah" is that I thought perhaps the next episode will satisfy my need for substance. Alas, there was none, and honestly I wanted to like her character but I couldn't. I felt like every time I was suppose to cheer for her I was glad someone else was pointing out how terribly narcissistic, hypocritical and in-compassionate she was being. As for the story I felt like many episodes left so much open too, no really closure throughout. I don't think I could relate to any girls in the show but then again I don't have many girl friends anyway. I believe in TMI, tact, and conciseness within my social interaction. How can a self-proclaimed feminist be making rape jokes and asking guys to abuse her?? This girl has REAL issues, I would not suggest she be a role model or voice of any generation.

Can a TV show be too smart?  I am drawn to smart Shows, well written, the WEST WING comes to mind, a smart show.  GIRLS might be too smart, hard for some people, but oh, so worth it.  Being honest the first three episodes were smart but not a knock out, then the series got better and better episode 7  - Welcome to Bushwick, a.k.a. The Crackcident was over the top hilarious.  Check out the award nominations for this show and see the quality.  Yes, it can be a lkittle crude, but that is part of the draw.  Lena Dunham is the driver both as Hannah and writing, producing, et al. She must be a genius.  Now Allison Williams as Marnie, Jemina Kirke as Jessa, and Zosia Marnet as Shoshanna are also great.  Try this series, season one is free on PRIME.  Highly RECOMMENDED

I certainly don't find this entertaining to watch on TV. I'm sad for society if this becomes the norm. I'm also sad that this show is named "Girls"--an insult to the entire female population on almost every level. Where's the hope and meaning, or even the comedy? I wanted to like this show, I'd heard so much about it, but I found these girls kind of annoying and whiny. I'm a woman who grew up in NYC, born & raised, left just shy of age 30, but I never had all the angst of these girls. None of my friends were like these girls, even the most flighty ones. Maybe it's a millennial vs baby boomer thing, but I don't think so. I'm also annoyed by shows based in NYC that are all or mostly lily white. I'm a white Irish Catholic gal but my friends and boyfriends ran the rainbow, Hispanic, Greek, Italian, Yugoslavian, Indian, African, African-American, Palestinian, Israeli, Asian, you name it.  Like any good NYC gal I could say "F you" in at least 6 languages, and the adventures my friends and I had were way more interesting than this bunch. I gave up on this show after 1 season.

If this garbage is supposed to be some of the best work Lena what's her name has done to date, it wouldn't be because it's pure crap, slutty, tasteless vain and totally immature.  This isn't art, it isn't insightful, it isn't witty, cute, engaging or any other positive adjective I can think of. This is just a failed abortion.  It needs to be discarded and new plans made for Lena.  I say that because clearly only the brain-damaged would find even the tiniest hint of humor in it. Makes me think of  some of the 5star reviews here.  What sort of person would believe this tin of cheap shots is Brilliant, edgy and truth-telling?  I ask only because I may now identify those who enjoy an evening with the crack pipe.  They're here, dragging on about this awesome new show.  Brain dead and spun out. Age has nothing to do with my dislike.  Good taste and a sense of decency do. Please dump crap like this onto the first garbage tug headed out of the harbor, and may it never surface again.

I like this. I have friends who don't, so let me make the case. It's gritty and funny and a brutally honest look at young women who have an extremely hard time at forming stable relationships. Like others have mentioned, it's hard to really like or root for any of these characters. They are all supposedly college educated, but they have no class and even less sense - not to mention being totally self-absorbed. And I'm sorry, but people are just not that crude - even 20-somethings in NYC.  It's a slightly more sophisticated version of 2-Broke-Girls-type humor, based almost entirely on shocking the audience with crude sexual dialogue/situations (and it takes a lot these days to shock HBO watchers). These shows like to fancy themselves as "edgy" and "pushing the envelope" but they are certainly nothing new. It's in the realm of the bawdy limerick or Howard Stern - dressed up as young adults in NYC. It's humor that aims for the lowest common denominator. Too bad, because there is enough here to see that Ms. Dunham is likely talented enough not to have to stoop to that level for attention...but it's working,

Laughing through the pain, after viewing the first four episodes....:  Yes, it's frequently funny, but most of the events involve cruelty, selfishness, and stupidity on the part of the characters.  Hard to find instances of loyalty or tenderness within thise group.  There is quite a bit of (simulated) sex, but the acts seem almost uniformly joyless and un-sexy.  I assume the show's creator, Ms. Dunham, is giving form to her own life experiences and view of the world. That vision is to be respected, and we are all fallen creatures,  but I turned off the TV after episode four feeling rather depressed and drained -- not necessarily the goal for a "comedy."

When I first started watching Girls I  wasn't sure how I'd feel about it after the first or second episode. But as the characters developed,  I really got into it in a big way.

The female characters play nicely off of each other at the beginning - all long time friends who have come to live in New York one way or another.  As time goes on the dynamic of those ffrienships change,  as fights,  bitterness,  men,  and life happens.  Initially, the twenty-somethings start off with ideals as most of us do,  searching for that great job,  trying to write the next great novel,their through the written word trying to be  voice  their generation. All the young women and men are trying,  each in their own way to find some semblance of a relationship - to relate to another with some meaningfulness.  Unfortunately, just like in the real world,  some are given better skills at maneuvering the real world than others.

Where others found the show detestible or disgusting,  I  found it pretty true to life. We're all functioning at different levels of socials capability.  You can see very clearly who has good boundaries and who doesn't,  who's screaming out for their partner to wake the hell up and get real, and who's hiding behind any number of things - from avoidance/TV, bring a people pleaser, to various  substances , to hiding behind a personality to see if you'll push someone away.

The series also explores sexual issues like sexually transmitted diseases,  the use of condoms,  abortion, gay relationshIps to what appears to be a very confusing, abusive,  sadistic,  victimizing relationship - which I saw as a man who grew up as a hurt,  damaged child,  who needed to know he was wanted,  loved,  and accepted for who he was,  but felt be was with someone who was only interested in herself - not in getting to know him.  From her perspective,  it seemed she was a very insecure young woman, who sought constant reassurance from a partner who felt she was all take with little give,  and was constantly testing her to see how far she was willing to be debased before she'd fight back, and they could break throughe the crap,  and get on to  the business of having a relationship - which neither of them has natural skills for.  At first I  really hated this guy,  and hated the girl for sticking around to be a victim.  But that's the reality for done people - the hope is,  they see how crazy the behaviors are,  and not want to  be that person.

I was So bummed when I got to season 2 and realized I'd have pay to watch the following seasons because we don't have HBO.  This is the type of show I'd want my kids to watch if I were worried about their boundaries.  We have 3 kids in that age range or just a bit younger,  and our daughter 'so have more self worth than most of the characters - female anyway.

Yes,  there is some stereotyping -esp of the female characters of  being weak,  not good role models,  not having much sense at all.  I'd like to see them  present these 20 something's as being far more mature.  They represent these girls as fresh out of high school or college And yet they're in their mid-twenties, without much sense,  without good jobs...  or not working at all and yet living in decent places - which just isn't realistic.

The one issue which was dealt with in a really irresponsible way,  although I don't think altogether unrealistic,  was the situation where the one young woman was touched inappropriately at work,  and did nothing about it,  as a matter of fact,  she told her boss he could F@@K her.  I understood that some  women initially would freeze  - it would come as such a shock to be touched in that manner,  but once the shock wears off,  you don't seek  out the opinions of others in the office and let them talk you into putting up with being touched.  You either confront the issue head stay and if it happens again be prepared to get proof if you intend to stay,  and of course if you aren't in fear of your safety.  A boss who's touchy is no excuse for invading someone's personal space.

I really enjoyed this show. It is riddled with uncomfortable moments filled with angst and raw portrayals of being that awkward 20 something who is still so unsure of who she is and where she's going. Entertaining! I found myself identifying with the main character and have come to look forward to seeing how she develops in the upcoming seasons.

My husband and I do not watch TV very much, we don't have Netflix or cable/satellite and we do not even bother accessing local channels.  Needless to say, we are not up on the latest and greatest television.  After reading about Girls and Lena Dunham in countless magazines and online, we were both a little curious about this show.  I found it here (used) for a good price and decided we would give it a shot, fully expecting to hate it.  We both absolutely loved it and it's become my new favorite show.  It does not get in the way of itself trying to be hip.  It's quirky and honest and a little out-there.  I am probably a bit immature for being in my 30's especially since I'm not having children, but I continually forgot this show was about people much younger than I am.  We get the biggest kick out of the character Adam Sackler, but truly find every character in the show to be interesting and fun to watch.  We blew through Season 1 in two evenings and were straight on to Season 2 (also fantastic).  I am seriously impressed by Girls.
My friend got me hooked on this show!  I only wish the seasons were longer!  Keep them coming HBO!! :)

I find this series interesting and amusing because it captures the Me generation of my daughter and her friends like a hidden camera.  The measure of success for this generation is to spend your life doing the one thing you were born to do.  I think Dunham accurately captures the pitfalls of doing that when you don't really have a clear picture of who you are. There has a lot of criticism of her unflattering costumes, nudity and constant assertion that she is just "15 pounds overweight," but I think these things are a non-verbal portrayal of how she doesn't have a clear picture of herself.  When she looks in the mirror, she sees someone other than who we see.  Most of the sometimes hilarious and sometimes heartbreakingly dreadful choices she makes result from this lacking in personal perspective.

Great show! I didn't know what to expect or what the theme/direction was but I definitely did NOT expect this.
It isn't comparable to sex in the city or gossip girls. It's definitely it's own show with it's own personality & theme.  It's much more relatable. (At least for me). I also appreciate that it doesn't over glamorize what females should look like, dress or behave.
 It can be bold and vulgar at times but it's honest & I find that refreshing.
I really love the characters.  Each character has their own distinct personality & I find each one extremely like able.
I don't watch much tv but I'm glad I found this one.

My favorite type of shows, especially comedies, is when you cannot guess what is going to happen next. Girls avoids a lot of your typical clichés which make it refreshing. Especially for a "female" series; there is a sorry lack of smart programming. So many shows/movies are almost insulting. Even though the Girls are meant to make mistakes and when watching sometimes you will think "What is she doing?" the characters have complexity which is usually reserved for television's male characters.
Much of this has to do with Lena Dunham, who stars, directs, and created this series. I was very impressed with her talent. Do I think Girls defines my generation? No - but the show definitely offers a different perspective than previously seen and I do find it relatable. It represents the time in your life when you have the education, and maybe even your intelligence has made you successful in school, but now you have to figure out what's next and how to survive in the adult world. The attitude shift in relationships is also interesting - the transition of the casual relationship that was typical in college to navigating serious, mature relationships.
My "Not for Everyone" comment is that this show has a quirky humor that you will probably love or hate. You will not see broad, sitcom-like setup humor. For me, I was laughing out loud (hard) through the whole first season. But I also have a weird sense of humor so I am on the same wavelength. Lena's Hannah is for me the most interesting. Lena is brave in that she lets her character do and experience things that aren't the most glamorous. She has flaws, but not in the silly cutesy way where the romcom heroine is just a little klutzy. She seems like one of your real girlfriends. Jemima is a charismatic actress, and her Jessa is a force that is fun to watch. Marnie is a foil for Hannah. She is gorgeous but also has her flaws. For me, Shoshanna is the weakest part of the show, but she is also the least featured so I didn't mind her too much. The up-speaking delivery I find annoying and the character is one-note (at least for this first season). Hannah's sometimes-boyfriend Adam is a gem.

Boring with unattractive losers as main characters.  Sex scenes seemed to be added as a way to attract  publicity.  I was embarrassed for the actors.  So sad that this kind of drivel is generating publicity.

The best thing about Girls is watching how these 20 something people make clearly bad decisions, and being happy to know that you were not that ego-centric or stupid when you were that age.  These girls are filled with drama they create themselves, demonstrate that they do not understand friendships, and make you doubt if they will pull themselves together.  All the while, it is hysterical to watch them screw up their lives. Girls is supposed to be satirical, those that get that will enjoy the show immensely.
Girls captures the painfully embarassing moments twenty-somethings go through on that journey of self discovery.  Fun, great, cringe worthy writing.
Funny and best season of  the three that have aired! Rewatched many of the episodes and couldn't stop laughing!  Good physical comedy!
Arrived quickly and in perfect condition. Enjoying Girls DVD! Very satisfied and plan to purchase more. An excellent value. Highly recommend!

This is a witty shows that you feel like you can relate to more that others. Its completely addictive and I can't wait for more seasons! Why must we be forced to write so many characters for a review of a show????

I assumed that a TV show called GIRLS would be superficial and boring.  I only watched the pilot to confirm my suspicions and move on, but was immediately enthralled.  It's been nearly 40 years since i started college in the midwest, but these situations and conversations ring true for my cohort.  It's selling dunham short to assume that she'll only appeal to her generation.  If you graduated with a liberal arts degree and no specific job skills, if you engaged in college partying and sex, if you hyper analyzed your relationships, you may see yourself in Dunham's characters.  At 28 years old she's already demonstrated her gifts as a director.  Critics who view her story lines as harsh and unromantic might be consoled to consider that, if your adolescent kids are watching, they're seeing sex WITH condoms and hearing down to earth conversations about STDs....and unless you've thoroughly covered those topics already, this subject matter may educate and inform their own decision making.
I think the show started off brilliant and original but becomes rather monotonous and dull as the characters grow less and less relatable over time. However, I may give it another whirl.

I really didn't want to lik this series even though I am a girl (well woman) and I love Judd Apatow and his projects for which I am a long time fan of.  When my freind made me watch it I was very trepidatious but thought hey it is only TV right?!  I am so glad she did get me hooked.  Very witty,  pretty realistic, and such a smart show! Kudos Dunham!
