I watched the first episode in a sampler I got of HBO sows when I purchased a season of a series - Game of Thrones or maybe True Blood.  After hearing about this show for over year and see Lena Dunham praised so much I finally sat down and watched it.  It was a head scratcher - especially the whole Adam thing and even though I was not sure I really liked the show I was intrigued enough to rent the first disc.  After suffering through the next four episodes I  agree with that doctor that you could not pay me to be 24 again.  I would have stopped then but I forgot to take the show off my rental list and on a long weekend I found myself with nothing to watch but the remainder of the series.  Good news: I actually almost like two episodes: Episode 7  Crackcident and Episode 10  She Did  the season finale.  It is interesting that these two episodes feature all the cast at a big event instead of little vignettes with one or two characters.  I also was surprised that Adam (still a little strange and creepy) turned out to be the most interesting thing about the show. I think my biggest problem is the character of Hannah.  Like many reviewers I am having hard time trying to figure out if she is parody or are we supposed to take her serious.  That whole plot line with the Boss was painful to watch on so many levels and frankly I think the actions that the two closest people to her took in the 9th and 10th episodes where the smartest things then did.  But having said all that there is something brave and occasionally appealing about just how brave Lena Dunham is to show herself in such an unappealing manner both emotionally and literally that I do applaud her for that.  Will I watch the second season?  Before watching the finale I would have said no but gosh darn it she did make me a little curious as to where everything was heading and if we might see some growth (finally) in our leading lady's character.

Lena Dunham could quite possibly be the "voice of her generation". A little help from Judd Apatow doesn't hurt either. The story lines are great. The dialogue is witty and interesting without being forced. The boys shine too here - great performances all around. The only thing that keeps me from giving it five stars is that the crying is not terribly convincing. :)
Each girl has her own quirky style that translates very well in this series. I look forward to watching the next season.

I make my boyfriend watch it with me, he says he doesnt like it, but he does (especially due to all the nudity or partial nudity present.....) Can't wait to get caught up with all the seasons! In this season, you find Hannah needing to find a job as she is writing a memoir about her life. This revolves around four girls, Hannah, Shoshanna, Jessa, and Marnie who all have to deal with their issues together. I'm not going to spoiler everything, but these issues include unexpected pregnancy, break-ups, parental issues, and all other kinds of crazy things.

I bought this DVD package from Best Buy because it was on sale, but I would definitely recommend it to anyone. The first five episodes are on the first DVD and the last five are on the second disc, making up a two-disc season of 10 episodes.

Now, there's a reason why this is on HBO and when I say that, I mean, this is not for the kids. Hell, I'm 16, myself, but this show shouldn't be shown to anyone younger. There's a lot of sex scenes and nudity, so if you're not comfortable with your kids seeing that, then yeah... I couldn't even buy this, I had to have my 17 year-old friend buy it for me and he got carded, so that just tells you something...

Anyway, I would definitely recommend this to anyone. I loved it and you know what would be fun? Get a group of friends over and watch it together. That would be really cool.

Lena Dunham is a terrible actress.  She has very little personality, and very flat to watch on screen.  But she's a decent director and a very good writer writing about a trend that has become so pervasive as to be a cliche:  rich white girls in urban centres who are too busy discovering who they are to actually grow up and take responsibility for their lives.

The dialogue in "Girls" is very good, but what's even better is its amorality.  The show's protagonist Hannah is both hero and anti-hero, a young women so at odds with herself that she just has no time to bother with anyone else.  If she's not mooching off her parents then she's mooching off her roommate.  And if she's not complaining about her friend with benefits then she's sleeping with him -- and often at the same time.  And if she's not at home loafing around then she's quitting her job.  When her boss rebuffs her sexual advances she accuses him of sexual harassment and threatens to sue, and when her boss laughs and tells her to forget it all she becomes angry at his lack of anger, and quits.

"Girls" is so good because it's so raw, unforgiving, and often at times so damn amateurish.  But when it's good it can be very good.

It is rare to see a show with female characters portrayed so true to life.  It's even more rare to see it in a comedy. Coming of age is intense and also absurd and this show plays off of that truth. Girls is clever, edgy and pushes the boundaries.

Overall Girls is still pretty brilliant and extremely well-written.

"Girls: The Complete First Season"
(HBO, 2012)

My wife and I burned through Season One of "Girls" in a three-night binge, and we laughed and cringed through Lena Dunham's brilliant and honest portrayal of these flawed but likeable twentysomethings. The painful agonies and sharp learning curves of young adulthood that have rarely been presented as accurately or with as much unflinching honesty as in this series. Dunham's scripts are intelligent and sly, showing attractive, articulate young people making complete messes out of their lives, stumbling through their not-glamorous lives in modern-day New York City, a hard town that seems surprisingly welcoming and warm through the lens of these young and brash characters.

There's a lot to like about this show - most of all it's how Dunham and company present people as they really are - inherently flawed, not easy to read, changing as they grow and have new experiences, appealing despite their shortcomings. The casting is brilliant: like Richard Linklatter (and her patron, Judd Apatow), Dunham gathers together unusual, goofy-looking actors, people who look like people you know, with big ears and crooked noses, body fat and funny faces, as well as young people who actually look like the ages they are supposed to be playing. Like Apatow's "Freaks And Geeks" or Linklatter's "Dazed And Confused," this show rings true because it defiantly gives voice to the people we really know and are, rather than a bunch of blow-dried, silicon-boobed thirty year-olds pretending to be teenagers on some generic WB/CW/network soap opera.  And the plot matches the look: the sharp wit and poor judgement these characters display will remind you of your own post-college life, and is particularly good at showing the kind of experiences and relationships that real "girls" really have.

Although Dunham gives a nod to "Sex And The City" (a show I could never get into), there's clearly a fair amount of pushback and satire intended in the comparison. These aren't oh-so-glamorous, oh-so-outrageous post-feminist stereotypes, these are realistic characters whose dreams and desires are bordered by mundane reality. The graphic, purposefully clumsy sex scenes do have a slightly gratuitous air to them, yet they invariably serve a direct dramatic purpose, adding new layers to the characters involved and their relationships with others. In short: well done. Bring on Season Two! (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue film reviews)
