Lena Dunham is most creative and talented, I'm glad she has a voice through this inventive program. I enjoyed the show, but there's a lot of gratuitous nudity. I can't relate to these young women very much, their problems seem so shallow. So one show is enough for me.

I wouldn't watch with my father or brother because there is a lot of nudity and sex and references to my generation participating in said things and I hate recommending we watch something only to realize it's super uncomfortable (aka hope springs!) but other than that... Enjoy!
The concept of this show is good....however;  the sexual content is over the top, extreme and not needed to the extreme levels it displays.  Sorry I waisted my money!
I love this show. Great that it comes with all copies! So I can watch on iTunes, on my dvs
I don't subscribe to premium channels.  Some friends recommended this show and they were right.  It's great.  Can't wait for season 2 to be available for purchase.

I'm watching Jenny McCarthy condemn vaccines on Netflix instead of watching Hannah and Adam go on their first date because instant video won't load and from what I can tell I can only download the video to a Kindle.  I'll probably purchase videos from iTunes from now on.
This is a really cleaver, creative, enjoyable new series. The characters are hilarious and quirky. I absolutely loved it, and can't wait to watch season 2.
Well written, clever.  I laughed out loud during every episode, which is not common for me.  Lena Dunham is a strong advocate for women.  I can't wait to watch season 2.
The characters are all so relatable and unique that its easy to fall in love with this show. You'll probably watch the whole thing right in a row.

Great writing. Great acting. Great stories...but too much emphasis on sex among adults. I like sex just as much as the next person, but it does not need to be the focus of every single episode.  Good grief if life were really that great ; )
I truly enjoyed this show and watched the whole season in just a few days. I can't wait to watch season 2!

I had heard people talk about this series but wanted to watch it all the way through, and it was worth the wait. The dialog is smart and spot on with today's women's struggles. Its funny but smart. Would be a good gift for a 20 something woman.
The characters are believable even if the situations are not always. The combination makes it worth watching and anticipating the next episode.
I haven't seen the whole series but what I saw was okay. I don't have HBO, wanted to see what it was all about

This shipped quickly. Also it's a fantastic show. And people don't watch DVDs anymore. Though they should. There is no better way to show your friends how classy you are than to have Girls Season One DVDs wedged between printed copies of The Hunger Games on your book shelf. Mix it up.

I have watched at least 5 or 6 episodes and at least 3 of them skip, stall and constantly have to reload. Often the voice does not sync with the visual on screen. I like the show, I just don't like all the interruptions. I wish Amazon would attend to this problem.

Here's what I got out of this show:

1. 20 somethings like to have sex - Duh!!

2. There's a whole generation out there that believes EVERYONE should help them achieve the success that they so rightfully deserve - sad but true

3. The thinnest of writing passes for great entertainment/art these days

The main character, Hannah, is completely self-centered and selfish as are all of her friends. They just can't understand why the world doesn't want to help them & give them everything they need (Food, rent, success, etc.) all the while barely lifting a finger to help themselves. Hannah seems to spend very little time on her writing and most of her time having sex and then hanging with her friends to complain how someone else has got it better than her. The show seems to lack any self awareness of either itself or it's characters or even display any irony in the lack there of. Unfortunately the Entitled Generation portrayed in this show does exist and apparently is flourishing. Enabled by parents and sometimes older friends who A) Either buy their BS reasons why they should be unconditionally supported (with money and of course no negative criticism) or B) Desperately want them (as in the parent's case) to love them for their own selfish reasons. The few voices of reason that pop up occasionally are given short shrift by Dunham's writing as though her character's room full of mirrors view of the world (To quote Hendrix "All I could see was me") is somehow valid and reasonable. As for me, the last thing I want to see is an episodic love letter to this pathetic generation of delusional cry babies. I would love to root for Hannah and her quest if only she had the slightest shred of self awareness & heart. What tries to pass itself off as self awareness ("I hate myself more than you hate me") is just another way for Hannah to manipulate and hang onto a benefactor. I really tried to give this show a chance (watched 3 season 1 episodes) with the hope that it would develop into something more but alas it seems not. Maybe a unique real female/woman's voice is out there waiting to be heard. And hopefully will be. But "Girls" ain't it.
I love this series because I am a 20 something year old female. I can totally relate to most of the story lines.

it's not really funny and i sort of have a depressed feeling after watching it. these girls barely have jobs, live off their parents, live in tiny apartments and have crappy relationships with guys...... i way prefer breaking bad and can't wait for the new show from the producers of breaking bag coming out on sundance.

If you enjoy good direction, good writing and good acting then this is not for you. I would describe this as an ideal enhanced interrogation tool. If this series were put on continuous loop and shown to a terrorist over and over, he would soon spill his guts to please make it stop.

I appreciate the realness of the characters in the show.  I feel like I was able to identify with each one of the characters on some level and that's what pulled me in.  I really like everything about this show.

This series is groundbreaking and unique. Wonderful writing and directing and acting. In terms of characters, the polar opposite Sex and The City. Lena Dunham creates an uncomfortably real yet still funny and moving portrait of young hopeful artists trying to make their way in NYC.

Was really skeptical about watching this show because its primarliy about duhhhh GIRLS. but its easily one of the funniest shows on tv and any subscriber to HBO should be watching. The second season just finnished but wasn't nearly as good as this first season!
At first I didn't really like the feel but after a few episodes I was hooked!  Can't wait for Season 3!!
It is available in 3 languages and you can watch it with subtitles. It's very useful for me since i'm studying Spanish now.
This is the BEST show, and the DVD came in great condition. It was the perfect Christmas present for my friend. We haven't stopped watching it!

Great new show. I starting watching it after my friends recommended it. I was a bit skeptical because all the shows with an ensemble of girls tend to be all about the same. But this show although it covers the same universal issues of transitioning into adulthood that the other shows talk about, all the time , it presents it in a different way.

You'll Laugh, you'll cringe, you probably won't cry. And, if you're like me, you might just start to understand a little bit more about the generation beneath you (or the image they want to project to the world).
I just started watching this show and I love it. Well written and directed. Can't wait to continue getting caught up on the 2 seasons so far.
Although this series is primarily aimed at women, I found it entertaining. A lot like sex in the city. You also get to see a lot more flesh in this one. Worth the watch.

Everyone is talking about this show, but they forgot to tell me it has graphic sex scenes. It's a witty show, but you'll probably yell "Put a shirt on already, Lena!" by the time you're finished with the season, no matter how cool and desensitized you are.
Love this show!! Lena is so smart and funny. Great cast. Such a well-written show. She is the voice of her generation!
This was a fun quirky drama. It was like a real life version of Sex in the City. Very captivating characters. It leaves you wanting more.

I really enjoy this show, but the price you are charging is robbery.  but then, I'm paying it, so good for you.  I will look for a better price and a provider that is more appreciative of a loyal customer

There are some great female writer/directors out there, Lena Dunham falls closer to the mediocre side of every occasion. One of the most overrated shows to come around in a long time. Critics scramble to look for a female entity to love instead of waiting for one they actually do love.

Girl power is a female preoccupation. It has always been that way. The girls in this show have varying quantities of it, and understanding about its effect on their world. Hanna doesn't have a lot of it on a physical level. There are  lots of camera shots of how lacking she is, but the show explores how Hanna deals with the lack,  the compromises and assumptions that stem from it. Lena Dunham takes the issue on full bore in a way Hollywood, assumed we didn't want to acknowledge. Women read magazines. go to the movies  are usually not interested in dealing with the lack, instead fantasizing the right medication, or the right make over or the right fairy godmother will give us the power to bend men to our will.
At the end of the series Hanna seems to own more of this girl power than she thought, or is she in the end deciding the guy in her life that she put so far above herself and therefore she was powerless in the relationship was actually much weaker than she thought? I'm concentrating on Hanna but the issue plays out for all of the other girls, typically for women it is the preoccupation of their lives.

At one point in the series Hanna goes home to see her parents, they too are put under the Lena Dunham scope, and they fair poorly in those ratings. Seemingly they hold or withhold the purse strings but, Hanna in this at least, can win that contest.

I like this show, but I  can't think men or boys are going to be that interested in it. In all of these types of entertainments, they are the prey. Helplessly they become ensnared and weakly they loose their independence, even their lives to a tractor beam of female power. They have always been made powerless in the fantasy and they usually hate to see it re- enacted. Men in their fantasies usually prefer to see themselves as physically powerful, independent and immortal.

This stuff got so into my head. It's really brilliant work. Great stuff to look at. Very literary and sickening. Watching this whole season on my day off, affected all my personal relationships. Though its affect is wearing off, I'm reluctant to jump into Season 2, though I know I will. I cannot relate to really any of the characters, and that impenetrable quality still isn't enough to come away unaffected from this great work of art.
Well written, smart.  As a guy, whose never lived in NYC, wasn't sure how much I would be into it, but actually not bad.
Fun, smart and very entertaining.  Anyone who wants to watch what it's like to live in NYC as a girl should check this show out.  The guys are really good too.

Heard the hype about this show and saw and liked Lena Dunham in interviews.  Watched t he 1st show and didn't love it.  Hannah and her friends...not very likeable...BUT - I watched a few more episodes and got into the stories.  The writing is good.  The characters immensly flawed, but interesting.  The graphic sexual scenes pretty awkward and uncomfortable, like I'd imagine watching real people have actual sex to be like (at least for me).  One of my favorite scenes is when Hannah tells Elija she got HPV from him and he comes out to her.  Could these people be more awkward and mean to one another?  Truly funny!
If I watched more that the first show,  I might like it more.  A bit voyeristic, but OK for we, over 65!

All I know is Lena Dunham is hot - Never knew anything about this show or her until I watched the Golden Globes and she walked on stage  - cutest girl I've ever seen - she wraps cute, sexy, and smart in one package - great face and smile - anyhow - never seen one episode of this show, but reading about it, it seems edgy and I am thinking of buying the first season.  Heard Lena on Stern too and she was cool.  So maybe I will buy this.  Lena - if you read this - WILL YOU MARRY ME?  I will cook and clean and everything and do anything you ask me to.  PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE!!!!!!

Initially tuned in to Girls to see the show such  young girl would create, write, act, and direct in. It is my experience that you either hate or love this show. I love it. It can be  disturbing at times, I look forward to watching this show on HBO every week. I have no issues withthe quality of the product  received.

I've heard reviews that this series is either (1) the best thing on television in years or (2) completely unbelievable.  I can believe both.  There are many scenes that are so awkward, they are difficult to watch.  But it's also strangely compelling.  Between episodes, I wonder what these characters are up to.  I recognize a number of these characters as myself at that age or people I knew, but I spend my early 20s living in a big city on the east coast.  Perhaps without that experience, I wouldn't feel the same.

What I like about this show is that its about 20-somethings, written, produced, directed by 20-something women.  It's not some 40-year-old hollywood suit's idea of what it's like to be 20-something and finding your way.

While it's not the "high art" critical acclaim would have you believe, it's an honest and uneven and interesting show.  It's flaws are what make it interesting.  Kudos to Apatow and HBO for letting Lena Dunham go with this program and do a show true to who she is and what she wants to explore.

I really hope real young adult women aren't like the jerks in this show. Granted, I was self-absorbed in my twenties and early thirties too, but these women are like a Void. They seem to have no real emotions except to be clever or taken care of by their rich parents. I hear it was 'risky' but all I saw was a bunch of low stakes plot points-- girls looking to get laid and make a lot of money without doing any work. Sex in the series is a total bore, devoid of sweat and fun. Why bother? Why bother watching this at all?

Brainy, restless young people in the process of becoming: taking what they believe to be great risks with little or no idea of where they are going, surrounded by a wonderfully irritating network of friends, acquaintances and lovers in a city of strivers and substance.... Okay, its true everyone is white, privileged and at least a few continue to receive financial support from their parents while they flounder about. But notice not one character wastes their time. Not all are aspiring artists but, with the exception of the ditzy Shoshanna, all are thinkers. So what I love most is the least obvious to the characters themselves who are busy living: despite the ups and downs and frightening uncertainties of young adulthood, what other version of heaven could be more exciting?

This series depicts the friendship between 4 girls and their journey through young adulthood. Refreshing and very believable. It has many funny but also somber moments as the girls navigate through handling independence and it's responsibilities.

Having heard much critical acclaim for this new HBO series, supposedly combining elements of "Friends" and "Sex and the City," yet not having cable, I was most anxious to see it when it entered syndication. But when I saw the complete first season available on a reasonably priced DVD set, I said, "Why wait?" When it arrived, we - my wife and I - somehow found time to watch an episode a day until we'd seen them all; early on, it became a daily ritual we both looked forward to, so much so we've wanted to see all the extra features (we've only worked our way through a few of them yet) and, if we can find the time, watch the episodes again. That alone speaks volumes because we rarely watch anything twice. It is gritty, funny, poignant, touching, and - above all - highly entertaining. One thing emerged in the first episode: the show takes full advantage of what they can show (and say) on cable that they can't show (or say) on broadcast TV. Yet the dominant theme that lingers in your mind is one of pathos and not profanity or porn. Exceptionally well conceived, executed, and put together, it is, indeed, a real micro-capsule of a slice of one portion of life, while we're all feeling our way, learning, making mistakes, and hoping, through it all, that we're managing to learn and grow. Highly entertaining, highly amusing, and - at times - highly moving, sometimes in unexpected ways.
I love Girls! It is am AWESOME show! Lena Dunham is a very talented woman! This show is so interesting a captivating taking you through the ups and downs of all the girls lives!

I can take or leave this one. I didn't care enough about most of the characters to want to continue to watch it but I liked Hanna so much and found her relatable. I'll be watching (possibly buying) season two.
I was so glad to receive this DVD. I am obsessed with this show. It is relatable and hilarious! I'd recommend it to anyone with a good sense of humor.
BRILLIANT! FUNNY! WITTY! SILLY! INTERESTING!  CHARISMATIC! CAPTIVATING! LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS SHOW! CAN'T WAIT FOR SEASON TWO TO COME  OUT!
I love the show and the quality of the viewing was great. I'm glad i have it on my computer now.
Too many awkward scenes. I mean really. Not that funny either. Too many cliches. What's all the hype about? New girl is way better.

Lena D is a great fresh and very funny voice. She is indeed something of a voice of her generation. She captures the self-involvement of her peers while still being loving. And she's so comfortable with a gal being less than an ideal beauty. You go girl!
Painfully real and hilarious. Lena Dunham is incredibly brave and talented. I really like that there are no flat characters also.

Realistic? For whom? This show is pathetic. Not one likable or even
interesting character. Completely ridiculous characters and laughable -
not in a good way - scenarios. Makes me sad that people think this is
entertainment or inspiring. Everyone screwing everyone? Yeah, that's realistic. I really believe, and sincerely hope, that
this is NOT how the "twenty somethings" are living their lives.  I watched all of Season One thinking that it HAD to
get better. It only got worse. And Lena Dunham, leave your clothes on
and wear more body-type-appropriate outfits. You are gross.
This show is great and different from just about anything else you've ever seen.  If you like Louie, you'll love Girls.

Its nice to find something unique in this show. Some people don't like the perspective....buts it's nice to see characters that don't look like typical Hollywood.  I enjoy the humor and characters but the amount of nudity may not be for everyone.

I wanted to see what the hype is about, and to some degree it is merited. Sex and the City with younger, poorer girls.  I'f like to see at least a little professional success for some of the characters.  It's hard to make it in NYC, but talented young people do occasionally publish articles that get a little attention, stage performances that are genuinely interesting, find engaging employment, etc. without it becoming the toast of the town or having a Warhol moment.  It would be possible to incorporate this without becoming NYC super-glitz.  Continuity issue:  How did totally WASP-y blonde princess Jessa with a British accent get to be cousins with fairly hardcore New York Jewish Shoshanna?
Finally, a show by and about women. Imperfections and all. This show resonates with young girls and maturing women because of its honesty and courage. Bravo.

I was searching to buy this title used and ended up here. However, the same thing is available elsewhere on Amazon: Just search 9781622241293 which is the ISBN of an alternate edition. Much cheaper, at this time.

Helpful? If so, Click yes. Otherwise post a comment and I will try to clarify.
great show - can't wait to see the next season. kind of sex & the city spin off??! love the soundtrack.
this short preview was OK but didn't really get the full episode in order to fully give a review on it

A person I know who actually is, in the position of being an intern in New York and happens to be a girl, says the show is not bad. It was only after, to my surprise, watching the two main characters get it on jailhouse nazi style in the opening minutes of the episode I selected to watch that i decided, nah, if I wanted to watch porn and boyfriends masturbating over the supine bodies of their f--buddies as they choked them and said they only had permission to cum if they asked for it that I decided, hey- if I wanna watch porn, at least I know what I'm getting. Not that I watch porn. But the person I know says the rest of the show is pretty good. I never stuck around to find out.
It's good, not great. The show is good enough to suck you in and make you want to show another, but after the season is over you wonder why you watched the whole thing.

The show itself is awesome - the plotting is thick, the dialogue solid. But there are few outstanding issues that must be addressed. Number 1 - why no blonde villains? The absence of blonde haired, blue eyed villains was quite disturbing to me as an Israeli citizen, if in future seasons one cannot be found by Hollywood execs (they usually seem to be able to) then a teen, perhaps with a penchant for non-consensual intercourse, would suffice. The second quibble is - why is there no sassy Afro-American friend - the streetwise straight talker, raised on the mean streets of Brooklyn, underprivileged but in possession of great intellectual potential - this kind of portrayal is conspicuously absent in television and film. Clearly every Jewish (or half chosen) liberal Obama voter, living in an expensive neighborhood with low crime would constantly be surrounded by colored companions of quality, so why aren't they included in this show? Women are portrayed as rational and hard-working - Hannah, a 25 year old English major, only asks her parents for assistance half a dozen times - displaying great personal responsibility, the other characters are likewise dedicated to their travails - forging a new America with their efforts, be it through part-time unpaid internship, babysitting children or answering phones at a gallery. Other characters only infrequently talk about their sex lives or other banal topics - their conversations are weighty and philosophical. Your shekels will be well spent on his DVD.

Heard about this show on the radio and I was having withdraws from Dexter. I thought I would
give it a try and I absolutely love it, the writer Lena Dunham is so witty. 2 thumbs up!!!!

I avoided watching this show for sometime.  My girlfriend is a big fan, and I assumed it wouldn't appeal to a male viewer.  I was surprised when I gave it a shot and found it laugh out-loud funny, and not to mention, an accurate description of life in Brooklyn.  I've met people like all of the cast members during my 8 trips to Williamsburg in the past year.

I bought this as a result of all the hype surrounding this show, and was completely disappointed.  I forced myself to finish it out, thinking surely it would get better/more interesting as the episodes went on, but no such luck.  I am a huge fan of Lena Dunham & loved her film Tiny Furniture, so I thought this would be in the same vein. As much I love Lena, I've got no love for this show.

I was hooked on the first episode. I am the same age as the charachters in this coming of age story about 4 friends in New York City. It sounds a lot like it will play out like Sex and the City but it is so much more realistic than that. I'm able to relate to the characters like I never have before in a tv series. Its somewhat hilarious and somewhat embarrassing how many of the situations these girls have been in that I have been in myself.

I've heard so much about this show and it's won so many awards that I was hoping this would be a great show. The pilot was okay at best. I will try another few episodes in case it takes a while for it to hit its stride.

This show requires some patience, as it took the whole first season for the characters to develop some depth and some heart.

Hannah is the struggling writer with weight and self-esteem issues.  Marnie is the "uptight" one who is perfectly put together but questioning her relationship with her sweet college boyfriend.  Jessa is that friend everyone seems to have in their twenties, who seems cool and confident and lives a wild, unconventional life.  Shoshanna is the perky college student who thinks her life is supposed to resemble Sex and the City - she panics about the fact that she hasn't had sex yet.

It's possible to find actress/writer/director Lena Dunham inherently likeable, but find her character Hannah frustrating.  One of the more interesting themes is how Hannah's insecurities actually make her judgmental and oblivious to others' feelings.  She also sabotages herself quite a bit.  When you realize the show understands this about her, and it isn't trying to excuse or garner sympathy for her - well, she's easier to take.

The acting and dialogue are quite good, although the more extreme language and weird sex scenes seem gimmicky and unnecessary to me.  This show will entertain you if you can find humor in the dingy apartments, career malaise, weird relationships and general dysfunction of being a twentysomething in today's world of texting and extended adolescence.  Not to say that all, or even most twentysomethings act like these characters.  But I think it likely highlights (in an extreme and funny way) the challenges of being that age.

However, if you don't enjoy self-involved characters or crude humor, this show isn't for you.  If you didn't like Sex and the City, you will probably hate this - Girls is a similar show, with less money, dirtier language, weirder sex and the main characters making even worse decisions.
HAHAHA!  Watch this by yourself and indulge in the fantasy world that is "Girls".  Nobody lives like this in NYC, but I don't care.  Looking forward to season 2

So - I was really surprised when I heard people were comparing this to Sex and the City. I have to admit I did like Sex in the City but in a guilty pleasure kind of way.  The show was brilliant and entertaining but I did not feel like I was watching a show that really said much and it was certainly a complete estrogen fest.
I was not sure how I felt about Girls when I first saw it - there are scenes that are mildly disturbing and at times mildly depressing.  But I found myself sucked in and watched episode after episode until the end realizing I was totally hooked.
The premise of the show is following the tough time between college and adulthood - the dreaded phase of finding yourself - for a group of girls in New York City.  I never lived in New York but I am not far removed from this struggle to find out who you are and your place in the world after going through the obvious laid out steps of school and college.  I think this show has a lot to say and says it well.  It is relatable and interesting.  It does have its dark moments and can be on the depressing side but I think they created something great here.

This series got a lot of publicity because of the Emmys, so I thought I'd give it a try.  I really enjoyed the first scene, where the main character is trying to talk her parents into continuing to pay her expenses while she is an unpaid intern, but it went downhill after that.  It wasn't because it's pretty crude; I watch plenty of HBO shows along the same lines, but I didn't find it to be funny.  After two episodes, I was done, and I was mad at myself for purchasing the entire season when I should have only invested in it episode by episode.  There's not a lot of shows that I download that I don't end up watching the entire season of, this was one of them.

I'm a woman in my mid forties and I really like the show. I love the absurdist humor, weird character studies and clever writing. The  strong sexual content was a bit surprising at first, but it's mostly hilarious and I'm cool with it. When I watch the show I may occasionally cringe, but mostly I just laugh hard, think "I wish I had said/thought/wrote that", and appreciate the talented actors who weave in and out of the stories. As a comedy nerd, I recognize many great guests who are excellent improvisers; such as Donald Glover, Jon Glaser, Jenny Slate, Bobby Moynihan...well, there are many. The soundtrack is good, too. I can see that it really pushes people's buttons and you can't take a lukewarm position about it apparently, it's so visceral. I would just suggest giving it a try and if you don't like it then don't watch it. Simple. No need to rant and even more ridiculously compare it to real life. It's not meant to be taken so seriously, but it is meant to entertain and possibly to make you feel something. And judging by the reviews, it seems to be working.

Highly recommend this show if you want to laugh out loud. The characters are great, the acting flows and they really represent a generation that is struggling to find its identity while trying to get a stable job in this crappy economy.
Very well written and completely true of life for 20 somethings girls in NYC. you can relate to each character in your own way.
The best show I've seen in a long time. You won't regret buying this dvd. You will love this show!

I was surprised by how much I enjoyed watching GIRLS.  Lena Dunham's writing is spot-on; her understanding of what it means to be a 20-something living in the city couldn't be funnier or more accurate.  Well worth watching.
This series is soooo good.  If you are a girl and love things that are on the edge, you will love each episode.  The topics are so funny.
Loved season one!  I can not wait for season 2 to available through Amazon.  The writing is amazing and addicting!
Very original, clever, well-written, well-acted but also sad.  I wonder if some young people really live and think the way these girls and guys do.  Not sure that I will watch any more episodes.

Girls is amazing, hands down. Don't compare it to Sex and the City because though they may be able four girls in NYC, they are very different. Lena Dunham is a very talented writer and director, and her characters are both relateable and hateable at the same time. Each one can be seen as one whole girl together, as each one has a part of them that comes out in a woman's life, but they work perfectly as single characters with awesome antics and awkward sex scenes mixed in.

Thought it is a great show.

After watching the 1st episode, I changed my mind.

It is rather boring with lots of small talks and sex scenes.

Some spoilers:

The dull chubby girl keeps talking throughout the first episode.

Very poor acting, just cannot stop talking through work, life, meal, sex....

At the end of this episode, she oded herself and finally closed her mouth.

The other girls also love chatting.  It appears that the functioning bathroom is a nice place for a good catch up chat.

This show is very funny. It doesn't hold back on anything, these girls talk about everything. There are some extremely awkward sex scenes which might bother some people, but it's worth sticking with it. It reminded me of my college/just post college days.

Girls in their 20s have a whole new set of complications such as is text the preferred method of communication?  Debates over this as well as career choices, relationships, and aspirations all combine to show us older folks what this younger generation is going through.  Great first season!

I love Girls, the music/characters/plots are great! Lena Dunham is such a talented actress and writer, director, etc. and I am so happy she made this show! The first season is hilarious, and well worth owning. Lots of good bonus features, but I wish there were more episodes with commentary (there are only three I think). Overall well worth the $25 I paid for it, I have watched this season numerous times already and I love that the digital copy is included.
I have never seen a show on TV that was this graphic. What if kids were just flipping through channels and came across some of these scenes? I really liked how it started, but I was disgusted.
This has to be one of the wittiest portrayals of girls today in their 20's, thank you lena dunham for being the voice of our generation!

I believe the hype. This show is absolutely terrifying and makes me disgusted with contemporary single life, but I can't look away. The cast is on point, the writing is good, and it's just too addicting.
Lena Dunham perfectly captures what it's like to be in your twenties. These girls may not have their life put together, but at least they have each other.

I assumed since this film had won awards it was of some value. Well how wrong was that assumption. I tried to get through the first disk in hopes that it would improve and when it did not I mailed it to our daughter. But then I felt like I was sending pornography through the mail. At 69 years of age I found this film totally degrading of females and hated the message it sends to young women. Then I asked what my 37 year old daughter thought of it. She too did not get too far into it before she turned it off in disgust. I think the best idea for this movie would be to destroy it rather than subjecting another viewer to this low class idea of entertainment. In other words, I am sorry I ever bought it.
Smart, honest show from Lena Dunham. I can't wait for amazon to get season 2. Love being able to buy digital versions! So easy to watch on Amazon Instant Video
it's Girls Season One and Lena Dunham, not much needs to be said beyond that, nothing more perfect can be combined!
The most relatable show out right now!  There girls are so wild and fun that you can't help but want to follow their antics every step of the way.

When I started to watch this I couldn't get through the 2nd episode.  I was expecting a younger version of Sex in the City, but this seemed raunchier and with the sole intent to push all social buttons.  I waited a few weeks to try to watch the rest of the episodes and they were okay.  Lena Dunham definitely has body confidence!  I'm not sure if I will watch season 2.

Some of the writing is brilliant, and there are some clever plot themes. But, depending on your view or reaction, some of the scenes are painfully realistic (and some are over the top ridiculous), and the nudity and blunt, graphic language make me uncomfortable at times. I was a huge Sex and the City fan, but they played most of the sex and blunt language for laughs very effectively. This feels more real (and also depicts much younger women - early 20's), and actually much more like softcore porn at times. It is strangely addicting, though, so perhaps that's my final word. I must say that the Hannah character's nudity may have positive affects for women and their self images though. She does not have a typical Hollywood hard body, is a bit plump, etc. It's about time that more mainstream women's bodies are portrayed on film and tv. I do not think the show is appropriate for teenagers. I'd say it's definitely for the college-age crowd and over.
This is a great show and for the greatly reduced price of the "normal" vs. HD version, I think the quality is really good, too.

After only one episode of "Girls" (the pilot in which Hannah wants to become ay voice of ay generation), I decided that I can't be bothered. I'm completely uninterested in the eventual fates of these boring, pathetic, twenty-something...well, girls. A few really ugly, disgusting boys have been included, too.

"Sex and the City", come back, all is forgiven - I mean, the men in that series were more gorgeous than the womyn. And I'm a straight male, OK?

Two stars. There will be worse stuff than this in real life when peak oil hits home. These girls aren't starving...

I know, I know. It's a sitcom. Whatever.
An amazingly honest and hysterical look at a wonderful  yet often confusing time in a young woman's life. Lena Dunham nails it!

great show,  became addictive to series after first 2 episodes. Very frustrated w/ inconsistent stream via amazon. My internet is stellar so I know it wasn't my wireless or device. When will season 2 be available for on demand!! ??

I love this show because it is about NYC without the rose tinted glasses.  I think Sex & the City is way off the mark in making a show about New York.  These younger girls are having a more real experience and it is funny to watch!

My wife really likes this show so I thought I'd check it out.  I was pleasantly surprised with how good the intial show was.  I'm hooked so far.

Also, it seems like this is one of the it shows of the time.  I feel like I have some catch up to do.

I received it from the seller quickly, but once I actually sat down and watched the show I was pretty unimpressed. I guess I expected Girls to be something more than it was, which of course has nothing to do with the seller.

I watched the first episode to check out the 'buzz'. Why the story of an average looking girl with a below average intelligence is suppose to be funny I have no idea. If this is her in real life then she has my pity.

I really enjoyed this show - I watched the whole first season in a day. The writing is real and honest, and I appreciate the different body types of the main characters - they look more like people I'd actually be friends with. I laughed out loud several times per show and cringed in awkward moments - mainly because I remember doing similar things myself at 24.

I had heard so much about the show from awards, news, etc. that I don't think it would have been possible to live up to it. I really liked it, but I don't think it lives up to all the hype - its a great, well-written show that portrays young urban women in a more realistic way - but it still has its weird TV tropes and out-of-character moments. Overall though, a fun watch!
Love this show, sometimes a bit too close to reality. Lena Dunham is amazing, can't wait for new series to arrive

I can't believe the blatant sex and language in this show. I think it's awful that this is what young girls are seeing as "normal." I also think it's a shame, because I think the writer/director is talented and funny. It's too bad she chooses to use her talents in this way, and that there are enough people out there to encourage this.
This show deserves every bit of the hype. the honesty in the writing and in the portrayals. The relationships remind me of my best friends post-college.
Girls is an excellent show, Lena Dunham isn't afraid to make fun of herself and she shows the strange, unique side of life that most shows never reveal.

Awesome!!! This series is intelligent, believable, sexy, fun and simply avant-garde in my book.  Lena if you happen to read this (which I doubt), right now, I am in love you.  No disrespect to the other amazing girls on the show but if I had the choose, I would choose you without a seconds thought.  You have this cute carefree beauty and you also have demonstrated the awe inspiring ability to entertain. Unfortunately, our society tends to push females toward groupie status instead of promoting them as noble competitors for center stage in all pursuits of life.  I can't get enough of you and your work so I pray you will keep it up. Touche.
I love that this show gives such a disturbingly realistic portrayal of life after college before you've found your footing. It's sad and hilarious all at the same time.

Girls is one of my favorite new shows. It is such a relatable show for anyone experiencing the post college gap. While you could compare it to SATC, and the show often references it, I think the writing is way smarter and the characters are less over the top.

I loved Lena Dunham's film, Tiny Furniture, so I was so happy to hear about this show. It's so funny and real and different. I am watching the season slowly, because I don't want it to end too soon. That's how much I like this show!
I didn't expect to like this show as much as I did, but its like a poor girls Sex in the City!
Even though we are far from our 20s - this look at Hanna's adventures is wonderful - every character is memorable.
I love the show! I watched the whole first season in one sitting. If only it was a little longer!
Funny, nerdy, irritatingly true to life.  Watching this show reminds me of all the drama I had in college, many years ago.
Awesome, hilarious, great new show. Was available exactly when it said it would be and was shipped super fast to me.
witty and honest. great characters and story line. The character Hannah who is portrayed by the writer and director of this series is so familiar and raw
Lena Dunham is perfect in this role and she leaves nothing to chance. I love watching her in awkward situations.

The people who don't 'get' the humor in this show must be missing the generic TV laugh track, or the pithy banal banter along the lines of something like 'Friends' (which I never watched because it was a terrible bore). I think this show is dark and funny, as two side of the same coin. It's really awesome to see the main character be so far from the typical cute girl - and for her to put herself in such compromising positions. A lot of girls really do this, it's just not so obviously self-sabotaging as it is here. There is a lot of reality, sadly, in this series, but the writing and performance is great, and it has a very unique point of view. If you need your stories to end happily ever after, then this one probably isn't for you.

it's a very funny show - it's real life,Hannah is great - lots of sex,smart humor & sharp, funny characters. the writing is excellent and did I mention lots of sex ? you'll download the whole season after you watch episode one, yep, you will.., !

From the positive reviews I thought there was some hope for this program. Unfortunately there seems to be no morals or positive personality traits in any of the main characters. If this is what the new generation (I admit I am old now) believes and stands for I am very disappointed. From the episodes I have seen not one characters has earned any empathy or sympathy. Every character is self-centered and very unlikable. They all back-stab and bitch about the people that are supposed to be their best friends. No emotional support, no morals and no thought for anyone but themselves. Overall a very poor display of humanity. Too bad this is type of program that earns awards. I feel very sorry for the writer and creator. She must have had a very sad and painful life to create such heartless and unfeeling characters. None of her so called friends are really friends. If this is an accurate portrayal of the way real people in the US now view their friends it paints a very dark and painful picture. Doesn't give much hope for the future. I just hope this Hollywood lack of morals and caring for your fellow man really doesn't influence the younger generation. Overall a very sad view of how uncaring and self absorbed people can be. Still not sure if this program is trying to be a parody of life or if it is just plain sad. If it is trying to be funny it fails miserably. It is a very visual depiction of very shallow and self-centered people making very stupid life choices. They all then seem to try to cover their own mistakes by insulting and belittling their friends behind their backs when they can't defend themselves. Always a very Hollywood practice but hopefully not a habit the youth of the US have adapted.

I got curious to watch this show when i kept seeing ads for it on tv. when i first watched it, i wasn't really sure what to think. Are the actors just inexperienced, is this just the characters persona or the person portraying really this weird? But i find the awkwardness extremely funny and relatable. I don't see any issues about the true light of life in this show. To me, its like any show that has a plot, i could care less if there's a gay guy, a black dude, a fat girl or pretty girl. I think considering its pretty much an independent drama, to be on HBO says a lot. Ever since episode one, i had to keep watching. It may seem like a flat show, but you have to give it a chance and see the whole picture. i hope it goes very far.
I love this show! Lena Dunham is a remarkable actress and director/writer! Everyone should check this out, but especially girls born in the 1980s.

Ok I read all the hype and while I am now considerably older than the demographics for this show I thought I would check out the last episode and well I am just not the target audience and really...get a job.

I love this series. I really admire the creator because she really is brave and willing to show vulnerability in a comedic, real, and loving way. Painfully real and hilariously funny. I felt sad when each episode comes to an end. I don't have HBO so I feel lucky to watch the season on Instant Video! Now I have to wait until Season 2. :(
Not easy viewing. The show is funny and quirky but also is gritty and shows a world that rings true because life is weird and girls face a lot of challenges that most shows don't usually talk about.

As a 50+ year-old, I'm loving the insights into the world of 20-somethings striving to become themselves.  Not sure if Lena Dunham is ultimately the "spokesperson", but the writing is fresh and compelling--I will keep watching.
I heard that this show was good from a friend- but knew nothing about it. I am utterly addicted now. It's like REALISTIC sex and the city for young 20 somethings.

I'm puzzled by all the people who complain about this show. "Not enough diversity." "Selfish, whiny, entitled characters." Duh - so? The same people would fault 1984 for not showing a more balanced view of totalitarianism. The show is not supposed to be edifying or heroic. It is hysterical because it shows us glimpses of foibles up close that we've never consciously considered but that we recognize instantly. There is no glorification here of anybody. To seek role models out of this show is to completely miss the point. If you enjoy it for what it is - and are under 40, I suppose - you'll love this show.

Call it my age and my experience , althought this series has gotten a lot of possitve attention I did not like it at all.
The depiction of modern educated women as so paralyzed in their lives is a trend that I would like to see reversed.
I know many young women who are sure footed and secure about their identity, sexuality and future.  What is depicted
here is anti feminist and silly not funny. At times some of the action is alarming making me think that young women are
being objectified in ways that are dangerous because they are going to injure their sense of self and they seem to be
aware and unaware of what is happening to them.  Men are still in control although also depicted as dumb.
Encapsulates the language and actions of Gen Y women beautifully. A far superior exploration into female relationships than Sex and the City could ever have achieved.
Required watching for all who feel their day needs a dose of negativism. This show will deliver the goods. I myself prefer a dash of hope with my melacholy, thank you.
Favorite new show this season. Watched first season now I'm hooked and can't wait for other episodes each week. .

I can't believe this is even on the air.  Once again Hollywood shows us how to be self-centered, engage in ridiculous sexual situations, and promote permissiveness and unrealistic lifestyles in today's society.  Bad stuff. By the way, I have raised 4 daughters and they have never acted like these girls do.  Not even close.  This show is much like the Emperor's New Clothes story, there is really nothing there but because Hollywood has to embrace anything that is out of the norm, it is getting lots of attention.  That really is a bad tendency they seem to have.  I think Lena Dunham is very lucky, but this will pass.
The DVD arrived when anticipated, potentially even a day earlier than expected. Regardless, the series is wonderful and a welcome addition to any chilly night lounging alone or with friends.

This quirky, off beat comedy delivers. Adam the boyfriend has become one of the most interesting characters, I like his often weird, but honest and real. It's not sex in the city in any way. I did take me a couple of episodes to really buy in to the series but I do enjoy it.
The show isn't bad but often times I find it just uncomfortable to watch because it seems they try too hard to make it funny.
About this show.it is extremely well acted . I am just not at all sure that I cared about the lives of these characters .

Amazon instant movie is great.  We watch it with our PS3.  Good quality, and we didn't get the HD one, just the regular season.  I heard so much about this show, so I finally bought it, very enjoyable, very relative to females in late teens to early adulthood.
This show just drew me in.  I'd heard good things about it so I finally watched and I'm glad I did.
I think this show is beautifully written. It reminds me of what it was like to be young. It's funny and passionate and surprising and definitely worth the money.

Supposedly witty. Not.
Uncomfortable to watch but because it's just gratuitously ugly like watching people roll in their own feces.
Realistic?  Oh please. Maybe this "slice of life" exists for a sad few but there is nothing meaningful about this drivel.
I don't go around looking for dog poo to step in and I won't be watching anymore of this .
I Love this new series. It is Very original and very funny. I hope there are more seasons to come.

A hilarious and painfully true-to-life show. Painfully hilarious. I am in awe of how much talent the writer/director/star has already shown at such a young age in this show and in her movie "Tiny Furniture." I wish this show had been out when I myself was in my first post-college years.

This show displays a reality that is often unseen in main stream television.  If you are prudish, though, this is not the show for you.  I love how the writers don't glamorize sex by making the scenes choreographed. For those who live off the path of normalcy, this just may be a watch for you.

I heard so much hype about this show and Lena Dunham and was very disappointed by the first episode.  Gratuitous sex and toilet and bathtub dialogues are pretty ridiculous.  I wish I had not wasted $1.99.
Lena Dunham's writing is awesome, but the show is sometimes marred with some sick or unpleasant scenes. I think this show is for25-year-old women and 50-year-old men.

This is a quality series, as validated by the recent Golden Globes win.  It is coming of age angst at its painful best.  My daughter urged me to watch with her, and I was reluctant, but it turns out she was correct.  There is a lot of nudity, and a lot of sex - a lot of very unromantic sex, in my opinion. Not only is it unromantic, but in many cases it just looked like not very much fun.  Having coming of age in the "peace and love" era, this bothers me.  Why are they having so much sex, if they're not seeming to enjoy it?  Haven't we learned anything?  Then I realized that the show has prompted the asking of some important questions, and I relaxed a little bit.  Worth watching more, I think, and we are starting on Season 2, now.

I love this show,  and find it quirky, funny,  & full of verisimilitude.  As an older mom,  who moved to NYC in the late '70s when I was 18,  I am somewhat abashed to find I recognize aspects of many of the characters and situations.  The story line revolves around a group of 4 friends who are new to adulthhood in the big city.  Yes,  it is often raunchy & cringe-worthy,  and the characters are sometimes unlikeable... but,  BE HONEST, weren't there times when you were their age that you were totally self involved & found yourself in situations (sexual & otherwise) that induce a mental and spiritual shudder now (now that you are grown up,  that is).  Hopefully, people evolve... but the process is often messy & painful.  I would like to especially note the nuanced & intriguing performance of Adam Driver as Hannah's booty call/boyfriend.  Breakout performance...his character is weird, animalistic, sad, intuitive, raw, truthful, & cruel...ALL AT THE SAME TIME.  I watch to see where he goes with this character as the layers peel away.  Lena Dunham has created a world that intrigues,  amuses,  & alienates...but it does not BORE.  You will love it or hate it,  but you won't soon forget it.

..and not just for hipsters. I am a senior and loved it. My 20's were nyc-based...change the locus to Brooklyn, update the tech and clothes and the experience is universal. Love it. Sass and intellect.
Very intelligent show about the adventures of some white girls in new york city.  Pretty funny, but not for yo ass to be like, why ain't there some black folk in this show?  Don't be a hater.
There's no other show out there like this one. I can't wait for the next season! Definitely happy that I made this purchase
This show is my favorite. I watched the whole thing in one sitting. I wish there was more. I can't wait for season 2.

I am not sure how to rate this series. As a guy it may be a little to girly in choice and may suit women more than men. I think it depends on your taste in the genre to make you own decision. I know it was nominated for a Golden Globe hence my decision to have a look. I think it boils down to a personal choice in the end.
This is a funny show!! Sex & The City for a new generation. Lena Dunham is wonderful.  The cast has great chemistry & is assembled of great new talent.

Watching the previews for this show and listening to friends talk about it made me think it would be funny.  The whole time my husband and I were watching we were irritated about the main character's inability to understand why her parents wouldn't bankroll her anymore.  This ideal that 20 somethings have that their parents are supposed to support them until they are making bank is just crazy.  Then the scene where she visits with her guy and they have sex on the couch- soooo depressing!  Not in a funny way, either.  The dialogue for the show is very realistic and almost funny but just not there yet.  I know we are always reaching for something different and fresh in our tv viewing but for me this is not it.  I'll try watching one more episode but if it doesn't pick up...meh!
this was a story as it was movie. Did not hold my interest but good quality. Took some time in the middle to upload.
Excellent portrayal of 20 something's in urban America. The writing, acting and directing is phenomenal. I would highly recommend this series

This show is smart, funny, quick and slow-moving all at once. It accurately represents young people and their struggles today (of both genders)! This show is not just for girls, however, guys will like it too (forget that your girlfriends keep comparing it to Sex and the City!)
I love the writing on this show and it makes me happy NOT to be in my 20s anymore!! Definitely not Sex and the city. More sex and the wandering aimlessly through the streets of New York.:-)

I gave this show one star because that was the lowest rating I can give it and have it count. This show is filled with one-dimensional characters that are in no way likable. I watched a few episodes and it seems like this show exists so that Lena Dunham can so off her and her friends sub-par acting skills and so she can get naked and have unbelievable, poorly choreographed sex. It's a complete waste of time and money.
This show is captivating. You can't stop watching, I watched the whole season in less than a week. Would recommend it.

My friend, Alandro, told me about this when I saw him at the food co-op recently. He mentioned how funny it was,
but in a totally not comedic way that's commercial and corporate, like most American television. I had a hard time
seeing the first episode, since none of my friends from Yoga, or the cafe down the street have televisions, but when
I finally saw this show when I went to Ohio for Christmas, I lol'd. I live in Park Slope, so I found these characters
relatable, especially the Dunham character. I decided I had to have the dvd plus I got a Tee Vee, with HBO in it.
(after all these years they got me). They totally get Williamsburg, thanks Girls.
What a rotten example for young women.  Are they to feel outcast because they don't have casual sex, sex sex and more sex, butt sex, etc. sex?

This show has become my guilty pleasure! I decided to finally watch the episodes after the wins at the Golden Globes. I find the criticism interesting-- and a lot of it is valid. For the sake of brevity, let me go point-by-point:

* No, it does not represent real life in many facets. No, no one can live in anything halfway decent in New York without a job. So, the alleged assertion by the show's creator that it reflects "girls" of today is wrong on this count. BUT this is a TV show, folks. It's not real.

* What it does reflect is all the angst, insecurity, and mixed emotions of life in your early 20s. The show NAILS THIS completely.

* No, there is not diversity on the show. Sad, but true.

* Yes, the characters are not particularly endearing in the beginning, but SOME of then grow on you. They ARE very flawed... which I like.

* I LOVE the unrehearsed feel of the show. The actors' lines run over each other... and they talk in a way with their volume, tone, and mannerisms that's so genuine and practically unheard of on other shows.

* This is a dirty show for adults. No way around it. If you are easily offended, do not watch.

It may not be for everyone, but I think it's a very refreshing and entertaining piece of television. I recommend it.

Lena Dunham is not attractive nor funny. Idk how she got into the entertainment business because shes just not talented in my personal opinion. i have no problem with nudity but this chick needs to cover up..the sex scenes were incredibly unrealistic and awkward and not in a good way. I feel no love for any of the characters. If you like good writing this is not for you.
I Pre-ordered this item and received it real quick. I have watched the complete first season and love the show!

....if that is even possible. Watched 3 episodes and can't find any reason to watch this show. I could not relate to any of the cast on the show and every male member is a total loser/dirtbag (and not in an entertaining way). I have mentioned this before in one of my other reviews, with so many great shows on TV at the moment (Boss, House of lies, Homeland, The League, Dexter, and many others) don't bother with this badly written and boring show.
This show has a certain "something" that 99% of the shows on TV fail to deliver: interesting characters that you will find yourself caring about.

First of all, you really can't compare Girls to SATC because they're catering to different types of women. SATC are older, in different parts of their lives and honestly half the stuff that happens to them is highly unlikely. I would know. I lived in NYC for years. Girls are just out of college, trying to figure out what to do next. They are floundering .They are confused. 20-somethings can see themselves in each character. They fight like normal girls. They talk about normal girl stuff like boys, clothes, makeup and why is my life so messed up. They even talk behind each others back. SATC girls never did that ( who doesn't smack talk their own friends???) For those who said the girls are self-involved. I agree yet say...isn't everyone? They're not anymore self involved than the normal 22-yr old. Overall, I loved it. I watched the first season in literally one day.

No question---fearless and great writing on this series.  But he whole premise of really really clueless, self absorbed young women in New York??? Although I know the show is sort of exposing the warped thinking...and making some fun of it...in some ways I find it depressing that there is a generation out there who has embraced sort of this slacker life.  Maybe it's a strange form of jealousy from someone older who has worked hard and sacrificed to make a life for herself...never thinking the world, my boss, my parents or anyone else owed me dispensation from the responsibility to take care of myself from a very early age.  But I don't think I would have been content to take money from my parents (even if it were offered) to live in one of the most expensive cities in the world and work an unpaid "dream job" and hang out with my friends.  I'll watch the rest of the season and try, yes, try to get it.
And I'm obsessed! There's a reason this show won a Golden Globe. Women and men alike will find its humor refreshing and surprisingly honest. I can't wait to get home tonight to watch 4 more episodes!

After hearing that the show was funny and well written, I decided to watch the pilot. I have been very disappointed, the show is neither funny or well written. The characters are very dull. Will not watch another episode.
I absolutely was appalled at the disrespect shown each other, whether in the bathroom or with sexual intimacy....It certainly diminished any love one might have for each other as humans.
Invokes nostalgia in my 30-something married, suburban life for the young crazy times of girls and lots of discussion. Loved it.
This is an extremely entertaining series.  Once you start, you will not be able to stop watching the first season.
The series is absolutely awesome! I bought the series as a gift for a friend of mine. I'm so excited about season 2!

I enjoyed the one liners, and am excited to see what future seasons will bring.  Very believable plot, but why must this kind of story always be told in New York City.

This was my first Amazon Instant video purchase, and I am glad we are able to download the episodes and watch them offline as I don't always have a connection to the internet.  Amazon, please keep that option around in the future.
First season complete and it is one of my all time favorites.  You will not be disappointed with this quality purchase.
This show is quirky and fresh and i love how real and raw the cast is. i have been telling everyone that i know to go get this show asap!
This series is incredibly lame and boring! Not worth the money, especially since there are only 10 episodes! I do not recommend this series, and it's not often I say that!

This show is seriously amazing. Granted, as a quirky 20-something woman, I'm in the target audience. However, my husband loved it, too! He finished out the season while I was at work because it is so addicting! I definitely recommend it for all women and the men who love them.
Hilarious!! Loved every single episode!  Ready for the next season!! Can't wait till it comes out on video!!  Great purchase!
It was moderately entertaining but really didn't find the girls or their situations realistic or very interesting. I wouldn't sign up for HBO so I could see this.

Prolly hasn't been done before, right?  An one a them cable stations
will air it sure.  An you don't even have to dig deep or anything,
cause characters being simple and needy and rude are like
fully...entertainment. That zite guyst thing or something. Right?

Then, 16 months later, with the show just an embarrassment, the creator
can look up the word "prurience."

I've always approached shows on cable networks with a sense of caution. For some reason it seems that most of the critics in the world fall all over themselves to discuss how wonderful each and every program on cable networks like HBO and SHOWTIME are cutting edge and worth watching. For the most part the one thing these shows have in common that is missing from network shows is the inclusion of sex and nudity. When the cable networks started original programming that seemed to be their biggest concern. Unfortunately that hasn't changed all that much.

I've never understood why that was all it took to make a show a hit. Surely this world is not so shallow that a few naked bodies are all it takes to make a hit series? Then again look at the offerings we've had. THE SOPRANOS, BOARDWALK EMPIRE, DEADWOOD and more have all offered some great story telling but at the same time felt the need to go after that base person tuning in by offering enough T&A to keep them watching. Would the shows have been as good if they didn't include it? I think so. It's too bad that these networks don't want to take the chance to find out. Which brings us to GIRLS.

Critically praised and already garnering Emmy nominations, GIRLS is the story of Hannah Horvath (Lena Dunham, the shows creator/writer/sometime director), a woman in her early 20s out of college for 2 years whose parents in the opening of the series tell her that they've decided to cut her off. They will no longer pay her bills while she finds out what it is in life she wants. Instead they expect her to get a job like everyone else. Of course Hannah doesn't take this well and blames them for all of her problems expecting them to finance her until she decides what to do or until she gets her book of essays published. Their response? Too bad, get that job.

The series, while focusing on Hannah, includes her three best friends as well. Marnie (Allison Williams) is Hannah's best friend and roommate. Her long time boyfriend also spends most of his time there and is oblivious to the fact that Marnie isn't quite so sure she wants to stay with him. He adores her, dotes on her, does everything he can for her and yet she feels there is something missing. Marnie works at an art gallery, something you would think nearly everyone living in New York does since most New York set shows have at least one person with this job description.

Shoshanna (Zosia Mamet) is a friend to both girls. What she does exactly I wasn't quite sure, but it's enough that she can pay rent and live fairly well. As the series begins she's something the rest of her friends are not which is a virgin. Shoshanna isn't sexually active which the rest of these girls are almost all the time.

Lastly we come to Jessa (Jemima Kirke), the free spirit who roams the world where ever she wants to go without a care in the world. Jessa is the Bohemian of the bunch, not caring what anyone thinks of her or her lifestyle. Jessa smokes even though she thinks she's pregnant, considers an abortion without thinking about it and dresses in outfits that only someone on either coast would find normal.

So what do these girls talk about, what predicaments do they find themselves in? First off they need to work. Hannah has the most problem finding a job. It seems she lacks the skills necessary to find employment in the big apple. Even Jessa finds a job baby sitting two young girls.

The other big focus in their lives seems to be sex. One would think in an enlightened world where the sexual revolution changed the way women were observed that they would hold the upper hand at all times. Instead these women crave sex and constantly seek it out. The bad thing is that in all their choices for partners only one seems to actually care about the other and he's the one who could get dumped any moment. Men in this series rarely care about the women they have sex with and act as if it's just something to be expected. It shows a lot of what the writers of this show think about men. Then again what does it say about women when their only interest in men is sex?

A huge number of reviews for this show have compared it to SEX AND THE CITY because of the fact that there are 4 friends who live in New York and who seem interested in sex. That's about the only way they compare. Where as SEX AND THE CITY displayed successful career women living out the fantasy lives that seemed prevalent at the time, GIRLS offers the grittier side of the same coin, showing a world where women struggle to make rent and instead of wealthy, handsome men find themselves in bed with whoever can make it there. Not meant as an insult but the women in this series are also more realistic than in SATC. No glamour girls here but rather women that you see every day.

I've noticed another common comment in nearly every review written about this series. The word "quirky" comes up in almost every one I've read. I guess the easiest way to gather an audience is to do something "quirky" and off the wall and you can stick critics into your back pocket. Then again perhaps "quirky" is a lazy way for writers to appear to be in touch with their subject matter and not appear to be unhip.

So with all that said do I really hate this series? Actually not quite. I mean it does seem more interested in playing to two simple crowds: those who watch for the vicarious thrill of seeing people having sex on TV and those who think they are so hip and in the know that this series reflects the lives of most everyone living in New York. I belong to neither group so the series isn't a must see on my radar. Occasionally it did offer a few laughs but those were few and far between. It also showed some heart in the fears and struggles of these characters, one scene in particular after Hannah has quit a job and found her "boyfriend" took her seriously when she said she wanted to break up. But this is not a show that I would set a DVR to record or rush home to watch an episode of.

It is nice to see the world as seen through real life eyes rather than the rose colored glasses everyone wants to use when depicting life in New York, lives filled with glamour and paparazzi everywhere rather than the low rent apartments and pasty white boyfriends. For people who love shows that reflect a more realistic approach to the world you'll probably enjoy this series. I tend to watch shows that give me the opportunity to get away from that world rather than roll around in it. I think most of us have enough problems in our day to day lives that we don't quite find someone else going through problems as entertainment. But as long as you know what you're going into before watching that first episode, perhaps you'll find this one you'll like but then again maybe not.
Even though there is only one season of the show, it is easily one of my favorites! I love how real and funny and relatable it is. It is like looking and my girlfriends and I
Although I find some of the characters whiny and childish, I did enjoy the show. And I think it is a pretty accurate reflection of life as a 20-something.

Something that takes the Sex and the City afficionados to a new level in the 21st century. This is a brilliant series; fresh, innovative, cheeky and insightful. 4 girls negotiate their way through the labyrinth of expectations that face young women in the urban sprawl of Manhattan in 2012; from sexual naivety to reckless abandon the girls journey through each episode culminating in a funny and surprising ending to this extraordinary piece of work from Lena Dunham.

I already knew that I wanted this combo. Girls is one of my favorites.  Although it was a pre-order, Amazon gave me the most recent price at the time of shipping. Don't hesitate to buy this one. It keeps you laughing.

A modern day Sex in the City for a younger audience that takes place mostly in Brooklyn. A great show about girls, sex, relationships, work and surviving in New York. Lena Dunham writes, produces and acts in this very creative and clever show about Girls. Every episode makes me laugh!

I loved Tiny Furniture; this is more of the same (basicly); but (often) poorly written; and only sometimes funny.  I don't really know why there is so much pornographic language;  sure it's HBO but when it doesn't serve a purpose (humor) it's just vulgar.  Overrated; probably will check out the second season, but if it's more of the same I'll probaly lose interest. Lena Dunham is still pretty cool though.
Funny, slightly dark, and most importantly - relatable for those in their 20s. Not for those easily offended by nudity or language, this show actually articulates confusing feelings of this decade.

An entertaining and humorous examination of fragmented, neurotic, and self-absorbed personalities in situations that had me chuckling and maybe a little annoyed at times.  It's bold and not "fakey-fake" like Sex And The City was.  Watch the first episode and go from there, I would not recommend purchasing the entire season unless you have already seen and loved it.  Loses some steam after the first few episodes.
Although I may have given this just an "okay" rating, I am impressed with Lena Dunham's work and look forward to seeing where she will go from here.
This show is amazing....I'm older and it facsinates me to see this generation in action.  Is this really how the 20 somethings go through life????
It it a good show overall......but my one complaint is there is no one to root for...none of he characters is very likeable but the stories are fantastic.
I like this show. Not the best but not the worst either. Pretty funny. I would recommend it to anyone!

Fun show - I discovered it originally on HBO during a long house-sitting weekend and really liked it. I suspend disbelief much like I did with one of my all-time fave's, Sex & The City, so it's easy to sit back, relax and enjoy the ride. It took me back a bit to post-college years which was fun.

Are you kidding me; she's not writing a story she's retelling her lifes experiences and damn well at that! Guys (forced by their wives or GF"s to have to watch this) will find this much easier to tolerate then "SiTC" , and they won't have to gut Samantha! There I reviewed a chick flick; now I'm going to watch Californication and Fightclub.

I don't fall in love with TV series easily.  New Girl and American Horror story were about it until this came along!  The content is racy and the show isn't afraid to take on taboo subject matter.  So, it's not for everyone.

Series also tries a bit too hard to shock with 4 letter words and sex that I really don't care about.  Acting is really good.

Girls is hysterical.. So well written, and wonderfully acted.  Although each girl is the extreme of a personality, it is still completey relatable.. I see a little bit of myself in each!  Super addictive, can't wait for Season 2
